HFECrzYDpgbS5EmTBtj2zQ.review_text: Magnolia Thunderpussy!   This is the first thing that comes to my mind when Capp's Corner is mentioned.   For those of you who are perhaps too young to remember, Magnolia's real name was Patricia Donna Mallon. She was a San Francisco burlesque performer, radio personality, filmmaker and restaurateur.  Thunderpussy operated two San Francisco restaurants in the 1960s. The one in the Haight, which bore her name, featured a late-night delivery service and erotic desserts such as "The Montana Banana". It consisted of was an unsplit banana, representing a phallus, served "erect" in a food service "boat" with two scoops of strategically placed ice cream, shredded coconut (care to guess why?), and a small dollop of whipped cream at the "tip". She created a host of other such delectables that, at the time seemed deliciously scandalous.  San Francisco columnist Herb Caen was an ardent fan of "Magnolia" and wrote about her often in his daily column for The San Francisco Chronicle. She was also very much appreciated by a legion of rock musicians and bands who came to San Francisco to record. Her catering operation would deliver her signature food items to any location in San Francisco at any hour of the night or early morning, and was hugely popular with the bands and their followers. She was also a big hit with the local "Cannabis Culture" who for obvious "Munchie" reasons, couldn't get enough of her fare.  Loved for her razor sharp wit, sense of daring and flamboyant imagination, she carved for herself a reputation of fun and free-spirit at a time in the Bay Area when all things seemed possible. Ah, the good old days!  During my time living in San Francisco, she was also a hostess at Capp's Corner - a cool family Italian restaurant here in North Beach. It was her name that got me in the door and the old school comfort food within this cool restaurant that keeps me coming back even today.

AiJ2nF4QIw08BuWWCUhXlQ.review_text: I grew up going here. My father was a captain in North Beach (lucky me!) I learned all the history about this place. I love the classic family style and the fixed priced menu. The atmosphere is comfortable and historical. Great drinks at the bar (stiff) and right next door to Beach Blanket Babylon! HOW FUN!

jmKtpUz93SGbbpRkp05yWQ.review_text: One of the better restaurants in NB. Skip the Stinking Rose (ugh, don't get me started on that place) and head here. Yummy Italian food at reasonable prices. The cheese ravioli is very good. Also check out the minestrone! I can't say much other than what has already been repeated several times but Capp's is very much worth it.

nW_QrEfNEMH5SE5tMy5xwg.review_text: Came here for lunch with my husband today. We had fast and friendly service; our waiter made sure we had everything we needed at all times.   He ordered Chicken Parmesan and I ordered the Spaghetti with Mussels and Clams. Both came with either soup or salad...which we had within two minutes of ordering! I even commented to the waiter about how fast it came out.  My husband said the soup was delicious and ate it before I could try any. His chicken parmesan came with both pasta and vegetables. He said it was not the best sauce he's ever had, but he comes from an Italian family (and we know all Italians love their sauce the best).    My spaghetti came with an overflowing amount of mussels and three large prawns and the most delicious creamy pesto sauce I've ever had. The food was full of flavor, the portions are hearty, and the service is great. This place is a north beach gem!

hnxKVPSR1xKM6qPBr7wQWg.review_text: Great atmosphere, love the old wooden bar and the old cash register. Don't change a thing.

wzSghdm84aLhIfnxanwBFg.review_text: the food here is good, but not great.  the service is very friendly, but the seating space is tight.  over all, my experience was not bad, it just wasnt great.  will i ever dine here again?  its a definite, maybe.

s5XJsJNNI944pvNKsb_OeA.review_text: Review of the bar only. We left The Saloon and headed to Beach Blanket Babylon but were early so we went to Capps Corner to have a drink. It's an old Italian Restaurant and bar. We sat at the bar and the four of us ordered drinks. The bartender chatted with us about the bar, the location and Beach Blanket Babylon. She had worked there for many years. The restaurant did a steady business. We looked at the menus and decided maybe next time. Good company and drinks.

NVei24-9k5GIZNRR1xGcRQ.review_text: Ate here 33 years ago, and then again last night. Hasn't changed much.  The celebrity photos all over the walls have been updated.    Place was packed Friday night at 9:00 PM. I asked the greeter in Italian for mercy.  We got seated in 15 minutes.    This is old school Italo-Cali-American cuisine at its best.  Family style, shared portions.  Minestrone comes in a bowl with ladle.  The soup was based on a fagioli mash with chicken broth, loaded with sauteed carrots, escarole, barley & potato hunks.  Goes great with the fluffy, tasty bread. Salad equally fresh & full of little surprises like big slices of sweet red beets and stewed ceci beans.    We both "splurged" on the $21 osso buco. Portion size was tremendous.  We brought 50% home in a container for another meal. The waitress effortlessly served at least 30 people without breaking a sweat & kept her good humor.   Capp's is an enduring landmark.  Eat really GOOD Cali-Italy food for Pasta Pomodoro prices!

FhkZk24n_Dh-pVLpBKUwEw.review_text: I've always enjoyed the meals I have here and I love the vintage ambience and the photos on the wall.  Great bar, too.  Go, enjoy!

QXRJ2akTpiiEEd0FPbfjQg.review_text: Classic comfort Italian food with a comfortable price!  I went here with a BIG group (14 ppl) and the people there couldn't have been nicer and more accommodating on VALENTINE'S day with a last minute reservation.  The minestrone soup is to die for and I particularly liked the family style way of serving of the soup and salad (made it feel even more comforting). The main dish was also good for the price (18-22 max!)

1aOld-llmxjrX5sL49-Lpg.review_text: Capp's has an amazing, straight-out-of-the-sopranos vibe to it - but the food quality just doesn't match the atmosphere.  When you walk into Capp's, you feel like you just walked into an Italian family's dining room. Big smiles greet you (and even a kiss on the cheek if you're a regular), with a general air of "welcome to the family". Raucous Italian discussions outburst at the bar, where the bartender seems to know everyone who walks in.  The food, however, is very generic Italian with little culinary experimentation. I tried their special, the Chicken Canelloni, and it was pretty boring. It wasn't terrible, just unimaginative. I wish I could give 5 stars, but this is a food review.  Capp's is a great family place and definitely an experience, but I'd recommend it for the atmosphere and not the food.

y4GUVhJtuaNifcr3sR6fgw.review_text: Great family style Italian food just steps away from Beach Blanket Babylon. I had the petrale sole and it was perfect with the pasta and vegetables. The boyfriend had prawns and fettuccine with Alfredo sauce. The clam chowder was creamy with perfectly cooked clams. There's a reason that this place has been around so long.

N49KzxE5E2Zs88ptsutAnA.review_text: Capp's Corner was one of the first Italian places I visited in SF.  It's great, homestyle Italian food in a family friendly atmosphere.  Great for a big group.  Definitely a good, relaxing dinner.

HZJA620xWYxaJI_PKbK0FA.review_text: Oh boy - Took my sister and her boyfriend here when they were visiting me and it was a cute little decor but there were a number of interesting things. I give it two stars for the fact that it's so old and the minestone soup was yummy.   However, our waitress was either really drunk or there was something wrong with her. I'm guessing drunk because her teeth looked like she just drank 4 bottles of Cabernet. She kept forgetting to bring us stuff after we asked her for things and she was slurring her words and kept wishing us a Happy New Year. The food was mediocre at best. We ordered the veal tortellini, chicken parm, and the lamb. The pasta was a little overcooked and just not very tasty.   The prices are pretty good but I definitly won't be coming back. I'm honestly a little concerened about the waitress we had, how did the owners not notice???

YE6MfcqTdqrqPgubWfYJ4g.review_text: I love this place.  It reminds me of the little hole in the wall Italian joints back east that kick out an authentic, tasty meal for a reasonable price.  Marinated beets in the all-you-stuff-down-your-gullet salad, endless bowls of home made minestrone soup (add a splash of olive oil to kick it up) and the veal tortellini, the osso buco, the saltimboca...  The Italian bread is always fresh, the olive oil is extra tasty (and virgin-like) and the service is always excellent.  Bonus points for the tables being close enough together so you can see what others are ordering and meet interesting folks from around the country who head in here just before the BBBabylon show next door.    I would have given it 4 stars but the last time we went in, they forgot to remove several of the bay leaves from the minestrone and we accidentally ingested a few.  non e' buono.  Been here a few dozen times and will go back many more times...

eo0tmepvnDLQfpY2O78o_A.review_text: I'll leave it to other readers' to determine if I'm a pretentious asshole or not, but that being said.....  Hands down the worst restaurant I have ever been in and I am a restaurateurs' kid.  I made the mistake of telling my waitress (great service BTW) that my food tasted "off" and she kindly returned it and offered me something else.  I declined, but was grateful for the good service and let it go.  A minute later the manager came over to the table ( I was out with my future in-laws) and began bellowing about how HE'D tried the food off my plate in the kitchen and he thought it was fine.  The entire restaurant turned around to gawk at the scene and we left shortly there after.  It was a lot of fun!    Anyway, service good, food overall OK, but the whole place stinks like urinal mints as the Men's is smack dab in the middle of the dining room.  You could not pay me enough to go back!

5tA6XMewAx5PWZHGSgwWbA.review_text: Nothing to complain about here!  We were a party of 46 and Capps performed wonderfully.  I had the pork loin, wife the eggplant, and both were prepared well.  This lunch was fully featured; soup and salad, bread and butter, coffee and spumoni for dessert.  We were served promptly, and finished to be at Beach Blanket Babylon next door on time.  I read all the Yelp reviews and none of the bad parts happened to us, so I guess I am lucky, no?  This place is not "fine dining" -  it is what it is.  I would go back again and that is a compliment.

vM8OfDVTkwkVNsdNaKeHYA.review_text: Well we're at Capp's Corner again!  What a great way to spend the day after Christmas!  Today we had about 40 people and they took great care of us again.  From the minestrone soup which is now completely vegetarian to the house salad to all the entrees which are wonderful to the spumoni ice cream for dessert.  I still love the calamari lunch!  Thank you Capps!!

bNLhIisdfB4je0kvq1bUkQ.review_text: Delicious food.  For entertaining out of town clients who want a fun atmosphere with a flare for the feel of old north beach.  Also if you don't feel like making momma's home sauce for your visiting guests - take them here.  The staff is welcoming and patient even when it is packed. I've had dozens of delicious meals too at the bar area after a hard day's work - where you can strike up conversations with other down to earth folks.

sFFdPjsKWMfZA0FbAK9pEw.review_text: If you have an Italian grandmother who insists on overfeeding you, this place probably smells like her house. That was the first thing I noticed, and I immediately liked it. This place doesn't have the best Italian food by any means, but it seems really authentically Italian. Like, my Italian relatives who are total racists --wait, let me rephrase...my relatives who really like Italian food and that's why they only eat at Italian restaurants would love this place because it's like eating at an Italian person's house. No I will not articulate that further, if you don't know what I'm talking about that means you are clearly not a wop with dago shame.  Ok fine, what I mean is they give you a lot of food, it comes with shitty white bread and butter, the marinara could be better but it's decent, the Manhattan I ordered came in this tiny glass, and the red and white checkered tables looked like they had been there since this place opened 50 years ago. This place is less upscale than the Olive Garden but totally genuine and has great service.   We kind of had to wait a bit so the waitress brought us complimentary garlic bread and charged us for a bottle of house wine when the bottle I wanted was out and she brought us a bottle of Gabbiano Classico, which I actually really liked and went well with the food. I really like when I get great service without getting smoke blown up my ass if I can say that without Yelp HQ taking down yet another of my reviews (I cunt believe those cunts sensor me like that when they aren't busy licking Mike Z.'s old saggy ballsack). Our server (Courtney? I don't know if I'm remembering that right but she asked for our names and I told her Lauren and she ended up calling me Lorraine which, whatever, I'm totally fine with) was really sweet and generous but she did tell us basically to sit the fuck down at the bar and she'd come get us when a table was ready. She kept it real, like this place does with everything else. Also, she was majorly hot and I'd totally scissor her if she's reading this and interested. Not that I'm going to insinuate that I heard from someone who heard from a cop that this place has mob ties because that would be fucking stupid of me and totally untrue by the way, but if I did, she would be like the Adriana from the Sopranos of this place.

I4fws8Fp2ornBJ_zeqlyMw.review_text: Sorry, this place is a dump.  It looks like a dive bar with some red-checked table tops (not table clothes, mind you) serving food from a can.  The soup and salad are brought out in metal mixing bowls with serving utensils that look like they're from Goodwill, and neither of which is any good.  Poorly seasoned and cheap tasting soup, chopped iceberg lettuce with some store-bought dressing.  Plates and bowls are old and dirty, flatware is cheap and flimsy with paper napkins and not enough of them.  I had the fettucini with prawns for my main...ughh, overcooked, gummy pasta, under seasoned and dry, dry, dry. The prawns were at least well cooked, and didn't taste frozen, like I expected, but weren't deveined properly!  Poop chute city, f-ing nasty!  The GF had spaghetti with meat sauce that was nearly inedible. Very Chef-boy-ar-dee tasting.  Didn't complain, cuz we weren't paying...it was a family thing...but will never go back. Much too expensive for garbage food.    One star is for the service...very well paced and attentive.  Never had an empty water glass or in need of a drink and very friendly.

CUwzHGjRPSNLEy6r-CrOqw.review_text: A Train Wreck That Has No Business Using The Term Family Style.  An Overpriced, Underflavored Disaster Barely Better Than The Spaghetti Factory  Yikes!  I only went here because an out of town visitor picked it.  The only positive: The hostess was friendly, helpful, and accommodating.  The waiter certainly was not.  The thick, stereotype/cliche Italian schtick did not help (and if authentic, maybe tone it done and focus on service it bit more; .and would it kill you to be a little nice to younger customers?)  Now, on to the food.  First of all, don't claim to be "family style" if the only food shared is salad and soup.  Can't we get that at the Olive Garden.  And the soup?  I've tasted better from a can.  The salad was a fresh tasting but lackluster.  My grilled leg of lamb was ridiculously overcooked (near mushy) and over-drenched in brown sauce.  For "seasoned" lamb, it was bland.  I've had 3X better at 50% the price at Opa Opa here in Sacramento (and that's a small, mid-to-lower end place).  As was the veal milanese I sampled.  At least the side vegetables were very fresh, though also overcooked.  Dessert?  Coffee?  Who knows.  They only have ice cream (that, as one reviewer pointed out, you nearly have to beg for) and basic coffee.  The places was so bad, I just couldn't bear to tell the nice hostess when she checked.  I often think that place near key tourist spots (in this case the hit show Beach Blanket Babylon) get away with a lot because of their location.  That being said, it's not a good sign when the place is only about half to two-thirds full on a Saturday night.

jxlwyBlSbYQ59IxVU70_Yg.review_text: Family style Italian food North Beach style. This place is in fact an institution. They make most of their dishes fresh here. I used to work on the wharf and would pass by this place smelling the beginings of Ministrone soup being made. This place has fantastic dishes and a wide variety of them.  Generous portions and served in a timely manner. The seating is at long tables Festal style also known as family style.  You get to meet people and share a fantastic meals. The hostess can handle drunks, tourists, old times or harried theater goers who are taking in a quick bite before going in to catch a showing of Beach Blanket Babylon at Club Fugazzi. She has been a fixture here for years.  The Bar can serve you up anything you can think of with ease and speed. Thinking of causing trouble? Think twice as you look at the old Louseville Slugger behind the bar which has seen several altercations over the years. There is parking available at several garages nearby but you will have to get there early. This is a must see if you are visiting North Beach.

zLHd86ObxLWdX34L3kUlGw.review_text: From the moment my girlfriend and I walked in here we felt completely unwelcome. The hostess was flippant and seated 3 parties before us who had arrived later. Waited 10 minutes at the bar before we even got a drink. Then the hostess didn't walk us to our table. The waiter simply asked "you know what you want?" The food was decent but nothing special. The highlight was the attentive busboy. We tipped him more handsomely than the waitstaff. Overall, a really rude waitstaff and a bad environment.

mB50b5XbG05whEBXkQRA-w.review_text: A family favorite!  A North Beach Treasure.  We just had a family reunion dinner here on Saturday Night.  The atmosphere and good service allowed us to reconnect with family, and introduce this SF treasure to our relatives from Italy.  Capps Corner never fails with ample family style meals.  A must visit!

rQrX_XZ2olx0lnZwAbAzAA.review_text: Inept service. They told us it would be a 10 minute wait and then 30 minutes later they seated two groups who arrived after us before starting us.  They barely apologized. I suggest giving your money to restaurants with the professionalism to take care of all guests in the order in which they arrive.

Iz6ajV7u5GR5UYuw2z7Smw.review_text: I went to this restaurant for my friends going away party. I was surprised at the pricing but I guess you do get a lot of food for it. I had the spaghetti a meatballs and all together I spent 25 dollars. No joke. It was a good size serving but not 25 dollars worth. They did also bring a large bowl of minestrone soup for our table of 6 to share, a large salad, and 2 loafs of bread though. However, I would rather have just gotten my one spaghetti dish for much cheaper and skipped the salad and soup.  BUT, the food was really good, don't get me wrong.   It was odd though, about half way through our meal the waiters sat 2 other people at our table. I don't know why they couldn't have moved the table since we had 4 tables pushed together and weren't using the 4th. Whatever, those guys got to listen to 6 college students reminiscing  on our drunken times together and plans for even more shenanigans for junior year.   Oh, and they get pissed if you split your bill with more than 2 credit cards.  Parking is also a bitch but there's a pretty cheap garage on Jackson street. 6 dollars for 2 hours.

sM9eEe423__2zdsXv8XJTQ.review_text: I took an elderly friend of mine (91 yo) to Capp's Corner for lunch the other day. CC was an old favorite haunt of hers and I had never been there. First about the staff - they couldn't have been more solicitous and helpful and kind. I was so grateful for their attentiveness. And then we simply had minestrone and a kind of Italian beans/green salad with a creamy vinaigrette dressing. Both were delicious, low cost and their was so much, along with the fresh sourdough bread and creamy butter, that we were stuffed and happy by the time we were done with lunch. Plus the coffee was top-notch. Therefore the 5 stars.

lF6EbR0ikhvegGdm4SetjA.user_location: North Beach/Telegraph Hill, San Francisco, CA
lF6EbR0ikhvegGdm4SetjA.review_text: House salad + soup. Chicken parm, filet sole, decent portions. Friendly and attentive service.

klPD5xE6_L-1fsMIHD5GYw.review_text: This was a nice family-style italian restaurant.  It had a cozy feel to it.  My guess would be that it's family owned because it felt like they cared about their customers.  The food was good, the service was good.  Overall, I had no complaints.  I've certainly had better italian food, but at the price point, this place exceeded my expectations.

vU9EkdRbQQr3V08mXmOmcQ.review_text: Authentic Italian....hard to find these days....come here before taking in a Beach Blanket Babylon show....parking a challenge....as always in SF....There is nothing on the menu that isn't good.

UBVj_v0JVMwuV5hqo-FDdA.review_text: It was ok.  I have experienced much better Italian places in SF.  It was crowded and the service was ok.  I was unimpressed with their flavors.

WdfVd3N3muedHNAxQuUktg.review_text: I'm a little biased towards Capp's cause I like the loud bar in the background and I used to work two doors down at Beach Blanket Babylon.  If you want a quite little dinner, then don't go on a night that there's a show down the block, cause it gets LOUD!  You'll be safe before 8 in the evening on just about any night though.  As far as food is concerned, don't go traditional Italian at this place.  The basics are not very good, don't do marinara or spaghetti with meat sauce or any of the usual stuff.  Get the special  or save yourself the headaches and get the Veal Tortellini which is epic.  The pasta is just firm enough to hold all the innards of the tortellini inside and the sun dried tomato sauce on top is just the right combination of spicy and tangy.  The portion is more than sufficient and depending on how much of the delicious Minestrone, made on sight, and house salad you eat beforehand, you may have leftovers.  Take it home!  I ate mine at about 2 or 3 in the morning as a insane dream inducing snack.  I love cold pasta late night and this was one of my better experiences.  If you are up for it, hang out at the bar afterwards with Terry and Rose.  Two great characters that add some fun and entertainment after a few glasses of wine with dinner.  Terry won't kick you out at the supposed 11 o'clock closing time and we managed to keep him there til the bar across the street started closing up.  I know some of the actors from Beach Blanket Babylon and they will be glad to entertain you with their antics and grab ass.  Be ready to be friendly or you won't have a very warm welcome and may get a few cross words.  Don't worry though, everyone is always welcome at Capps as long as you are ready to take and give a smile.

X-GtUMe6QSoPE_kkiXkJKQ.review_text: I thought the rude reservations was just a part of the charm until our reservation for 12 for a birthday party showed up and the restaurant said they "lost" it.  F' that place!

ehIpQo8mQHxhNIq7WAwKFw.review_text: Old school family type restaurant, but they've added a bit of modern touches to it, like the 2 tvs by the bar.  Old school cash register with a mini credit card swiper to the side. All the tables are long and can seat a group of 4-20 people. You don't want to come here alone anyways because the food portions are huge and family style.  I have only tasted the bar so far but am tempted to return to try some

zpXqbJQ2CT4PsUBTy30DbQ.review_text: Great little family owned, family style Italian restaurant.  The wine is SOOOO cheap.  Had a glass of Chianti for $3.50.  Love the ambience and not so crowded feel.  You automatically get really, really good, hearty minestrone soup to start no matter what entree you choose.  Then comes toe salad which is awesome as well served with beets, chickpeas, and another sort of beans in a creamy Italian-esque dressing.  There are about 10 options for $17 and 10 option for $20.  The pastas are on the cheaper side.  My friend ordered penne with marinara which looked great. I had the chick parm, which was delicious. Came with a small side of penne and a squash and carrot melange of veggies.  Overall, 4 stars b/c the service is kinda slow. but other than that, everything was fab. Loved the ambient feel of this place.

8YGHgREwGVHE5WKXDk1DIg.review_text: I ate here last night by total accident (the place we intended to go was mysteriously closed on a friday night) and I am so glad! It smelled delightful from outside, and the three of us were hungry so we decided to give it a shot. After a brief wait at the bar (bartenders were friendly and skilled) we sat down and eagerly eyed the menu. Ordering is made simple, two categories of entrees ($17.50 or $20.00) and everything else is included.   Between the three of us, Roasted Lamb, Veal Cannelloni and cheese ravioli was ordered. along with the entrees came a large tureen of minestrone soup and another large tureen of clam chowder (so good!) then there was salad and of course bread. Meat entrees also came with veggies and pasta on the plate. Trust me when I say you won't leave hungry!  The staff was great. We never had to wait for anything we requested, and I watched in awe as our waitress dealt with *very* rude customers with total grace. Leave your diet at the door and enjoy a lovely meal- bring friends for maximum good time (this place is not another cozy, dark italian place in north beach)

zW6RawW6kK8sKA2ruDKhMg.review_text: I came here for the first time after with some family visiting from out of town, mostly because we wanted to show them the area and they could accommodate the size of our party.  I won't go back, at least not for the food.  They say they are family style, which to me sounds like large portions and sharing entrees.  Their version of family style means that they bring out the soup and salad in big bowls and you serve yourself from the communal bowls.  That's cool, the minestrone was alright.  In general the service was ok, but not friendly.  I ordered the Lasagna which was fine, but completely forgettable.  Portions were about right, but certainly not large enough to share.    Basically, it wasn't what I expected and it wasn't terribly good.  I wish we had gone to Valencia Pizza and Pasta in the Mission.

NrxsUYEx6wEMSXjSM6Omlw.review_text: **AVOID THIS PLACE***  I was very disappointed in this place.  I have heard great reviews from friends and now that I have told them what happened they also are very disappointed.  We went and had reservations as a group of 14. There was a bartender that had an attitude of a nat.  When I expressed I wanted a drink that he didnt know how to make he just had this look like, "Really?" I explained how to make it then the glass was left with over an inch of empty glass to the top. Then you basically charge me $10.00 for a drink that was not even filled to the top of the glass.  Other people ordered drinks and they were charged $8.00 and they still didnt have the glasses filled all the way.  Maybe you should get smaller glasses.  OHHH WAIT.. You had smaller glass that a friend got a vodka and cranberry in and it was Very Cranberry with very little vodka. Then during the Bartender change over, The newer one apparently was a New hire and still learning.  The Food was nothing real special and very bland. Everything including the soup tasted like it was out of cans.  I don't mind canned stuff but you could add seasoning and spices. The Burnt garlic bread that came out was.. ummmm Burnt... But it did have garlic seasoning. =) I ordered t he soup, Pasta and salad for like $15.50 and the meat sauce was bland. But... The noodles were cooked well.  The Waitress with an attitude. Let me see Where do I start,  Where she asked us to hurry up and finish our food and drinks and was not going to offer dessert?  She wanted to tables for others that were not even there. She had short Black hair, White top and top heavy. She was very rude to some of the people in the party and her tone needed adjustment.  When I asked her name I think she said Sherry, then she said; "  And you can call my boss tomorrrow if you want." So, She already knew she was rude.  She made comments to the other servers and they just laughed it off and her body language towards us was un acceptable.   We went here because we were going to BBB and I am not sure if the restraunt is used to just locals but I would never reccommend this to anyone. Such a shame.  I just called to speak with the manager He said he was John and He said he was sorry, as I was just expressing more detail and he said he was not going to fire her but he'll have a talk with her and he hung up the phone.  WOW these people have no manners or consideration.

kTUQpHyIW-W9Hi537DyQAA.review_text: Good food and great for before or after the Beach Blanket Babylon show since it is next door. I didn't like paying 10 bucks to split my husband dinner when all I wanteed was soup and salad. We were short on time because I needed to get in line for the show. I actually had to leave before the veal tortellini arrived.My husband said it was good. I also liked the atmosphere. I would return. The soup was great.

lTRdr5P664kWt4woydLbuQ.review_text: If you like bland, tasteless food, you're going to love the penne meat bolognese at Capp's!

xLVHXFZ1gi6xP5L_AmUxFg.review_text: This is my first Yelp review, and I had to do it...because I was so disappointed in Capp's corner.  My husband and I just moved to San Francisco and we decided to go to North Beach and have a nice Italian dinner.  I hate to say it but this restaurant gave us such a bad impression of North Beach as an overrated tourist trap.  The decor was cool, in that old school, family-style Italian way, and our server was nice.  But...the food! What a buzzkill!  I mean we were really psyched to be in a new city about to get some authentic Italian food in cozy Italian North Beach and it just wasn't good.  The food was bland and basic.  My ravioli tasted like chef-boyardee!  I hate chef-boyardee!  The sauce tasted like it came from a jar.  Real Italian cooking is based on the idea of using simple, fresh, seasonal ingredients.  This place tasted like everything was pre-made and definitely not fresh and flavorful.  I probably should tell you that I grew up Italian-American in New York, with AMAZING cooks in my family.  I'm very spoiled when it comes to Italian-American cooking (and my husband is too now, by association).  Needless to say, the place was cute, but it really was not an enjoyable meal because of the food.  We definitely would not go back to Capp's corner.  I can cook better pasta at home for an eighth of the price.  We just left feeling like we totally made a bad choice and wasted a ton of calories for our "welcome-to-san-fran-north-beach-date-night-­dinner".  I guess this place would be cool if you didn't know "real" italian-american cooking, but if you do, then don't bother.

CE94k01X3W3TnBwOZb3HQw.review_text: Went for dinner on a Sunday evening.  It wasn't crowded by the time we walked over around 5pm. The menu all looked so good, but we ordered the linguine with marina mussels and clams  & the fettucini with prawns in white wine sauce.  The server was attentive and polite but didn't smile the entire time.  The buser was very attentive and our water cups never got ignored ( i love that bc i drink a lot of water )  Also, the buser cleared our plates quickly and the server never crowded the table... we got everything after we had obviously  finished the prior dish.      This place has a comfy feel and not in the dive bar kinda way, but a homey one.  It has a lot of seating and the cost of dinner for 2 plus wine was less than $60.  It's a great place for a date and also big family gettogethers.  I have been before and will definitely be going again.  4 stars because the waiter didn't smile enough  the service was good, but not beyond exemplarily

1m4Hmm7IbgGjVupM7CQSMw.review_text: love the feel of the place...totally old school northbeach. The waitress was awesome. Food was kinda bland and pretty overpriced considering what it is. I'd totally go there for family style soup tho! :)

Uuhb9K_AsOST6A7yKpIuBA.review_text: Capp's Corner has a special place in my heart. We stumbled upon this Italian jewel  a few years ago and have been going back ever since. I love the decor! Old School. They used to have a neon sign that said Capps Corner inside the restaurant. The last time we ate at Capp's the sign was gone...but the great service and delicious spaghetti and meatballs were still there. The bread and soup are excellent too. I like everything about this place. If you're a pretentious asshole you might not like this place.

OYR-CS6ejlwQI7u64dBSXw.review_text: This place is a good, basic, all-around Italian restaurant.  You really can't go wrong here.  The portions are good, the flavors are good, the service is good.  The prices could be a little better, but hey, it's in SF.  I would go back.

EuVIu9CfmsWX8hkAnZsQFg.review_text: We had a pleasant lunch here over the weekend.  The service was fabulous and the atmosphere is really cozy.  The minestrone soup and salad were really excellent.  My dining partner enjoyed the italian sausage sandwich.  My pasta dish was ok, but the shrimp was overcooked and the pasta sauce was a little short on flavor.

WMfhqsUYtoY2ugRaiKoPJQ.review_text: Food is below average Italian American diner schlop but the nail in the coffin is a $10 charge to split an entree.  Bullshit!

1I1Zr6yuTkyPRiqe8qD5Ow.review_text: I love this place and go as often as possible. North Beach at it's best, old school, family style, great food and they don't rake you over the coals when the bill comes. Plus great service with a real family feel.  Dinner for two: 2 Cocktails Soup, salad & delicious Italian bread 2 Entrees  A bottle of Pinot Grigio  and 2 shots of Fernet for dessert :) all for 80 bucks, you just can't go wrong. Like i said, I love this place!

e2MIDX_YWVVQl7-t-SJf-w.review_text: A solid place to go before Beach Blanket Babylon (then to North Star, of course).  Is it a place I want to go to every weekend?  No.  I'm satisfied if I go there once every 2 years.  You go more for the charm than for the food.     I also go because the corkage is only $10!

ueYNL6GNxCz2Pm4ZP8vpOQ.review_text: I want to say as an update to my review that the following individuals are to be the best there is at Capps. Joe the bartender who works the weekends is the best bartender that I have known who really knows how to make everyone happy and is down right the best. He has the greatest attitude and the he also makes the best drinks.Besides that he also knows many things about the city. Then there is Jack. He has the funniest comments and knows quite a lot about the area and very up to date on news and other things happening around the city and last but never least is Nicky. This waiter and all around knowledgeable person is so kind and easy going and never seems to get upset about anything. This place is fantastic.

eX35VTC_tQH8TqygIrUo2Q.review_text: We aren't picky. Went for a nice family dinner Sunday night. My sons fettuccine Alfredo ( they said sorry ran out if fettuccine we gave you spaghetti  ) was barely edible. I ordered pasta garlic tomatoes. Tried adding as much salt as I could to season it. Horrible. Won't be back. Employees were friendly.  I just was disappointed that our night in North Beach was celebrated with bad food.

UuxiH2oLycDhMv7TKQ5EVw.review_text: Ever want to feel like you're in an episode of The Soprano's or Goodfellas or something? Go in and have a drink or two at Capp's.   This place is decked out like a classic Italian diner, the red checkered tables, the smell of pasta and meatballs, classic old wood bar, the works. When you think of an old style North Beach eatery, this place is one that should come to mind.   I wish I could comment on the food here but alas, I've only ever had cocktails here. I definitely intend to enjoy a meal here after the few times I've enjoyed drinks in there.  Salute!

m6p5knAyIS79s6WNbeIdGw.review_text: Nothing fancy but very enjoyable. The service was solid, the prices are very reasonable (especially for wine) and the food was basic yet yummy. I sat here last night for hours drinking wine and enjoying yummy Italian food. I will definitely be back.

G5Ykk0BSuDNsoXeLrIyZcA.review_text: somebody took the ronald reagan picture off the wall! it was there for as long as i can remember.now when i walk in the first thing is "where is reagans picture"? the cook manny is top notch,i prabably won't return untill reagan comes back.

6KwXl86DhNZn2nJH8GcdIw.review_text: They are lucky I need to add a star, because honestly this place deserve 0 stars. The atmosphere was great it felt like a real old San Francisco spot, but the food was TERRIBLE !!!!! The restaurant was very full and me and my husband, son and sister we were excited to eat some good Italian food. The waitress she was good busy as hell since the place was packed and she was the only waitress.  Suddenly she brought us soup , everything in the soup since is part of the family meal, all the ingredients of the soup were out of the can that automatically start giving me pain in my stomach. Than a hour later they brought was the salad swimming in sauce(dressing) there were so much dressing that was nasty to eat. The salad was complete with thousand island dressing and can beans and can garbanzo beans. We all start to be nervous about our meal that was about to come. When finally the food arrived almost a hour later, it was horrible the vegetables were swimming in butter and super soft. I order the chicken parmigiana what was full of marinara sauce and the chicken it self had no flavor it just taste like chicken. The pasta was over cooked and with marina sauce. I felt like I was eating in a all inclusive buffet, I even think that all inclusive buffet would be better. My husbands food was terrible as well he order the sole and was burned, my sister osso buck was so nasty that she tried and was not able to eat. The polenta that came in her plate was so horrible so horrible that I don't think I have words to describe. The worst of all was the time that took for the food to arrive, my son who is 3 had to wait almost 2 hours for a plate with pasta and tomato sauce. Seriously. Just very disappointed I have been in SF for 10 year and have never ate that bad.

OBzOoEpUTXgC8YONTygyNQ.review_text: Truly disgusting! I was there the other night and watched a bartender who had poured too much club soda into a drink, realize it then pour it through his fingers into another glass and serve it. A few minutes later I watched a waitress fish out a piece of cork from a glass of red wine with her fingers and take it to the table.  This place is really nasty!  The wine, by the way,  was Crane Lake (about  $5.50 a glass)  which sells at your local overpriced corner store for about $5.50 a bottle.

Xj0O2l0bp633ebmG468aZw.review_text: Came back after almost 10 years. Huge delicious portions. I used to think it was expensive - now I think it's cheap. Soup still rocks (minestrone doesn't describe it - it's a yummy bean soup.) REALLY NICE SERVER.

CxzDJHk4P1tA-ze3hrEyhA.review_text: Best Italian food I've had in California, and the staff is very attentive.  The portions are unreal, and the cost is quite reasonable given the large portions.  I highly recommend the minestrone.

6YnpPhuKaGUDOEIpkR7uFA.review_text: Excellent Italian restaurant. It's family style which makes it even that much better. Had the Red Snapper in a lemon butter sauce... umm... yeah, sooo good! Their spaghetti and meatballs was also fabulous. And their linguini with claims and mussels in a white wine sauce. All dishes were great in a very friendly atmosphere. Oh and the bottle of Cab was dope too. Overall, excellent experience and excellent food.

luJuzuWOpA7bF0V2b-OVuw.review_text: My friends and I came here a couple of weeks ago after the North Beach Festival. We were a party of 8 who showed up unexpected and only had to wait about a 1/2 hr for a table. For such a small place I was shocked that it was only that long. They had a great family style serving for the beginning salad and soup courses and then our entrees came out at a reasonable time.  Service was great except towards the end when the waitress didn't want to split our checks and said we could walk across the street to get cash out, we fought her a bit and she finally said she would do it. We weren't being difficult with different charges, just wanted the bill to be divided equally between us all. Other then that, it was a great experience. Would definitely come back again!

IdU4HMUZFzN63_bGfn66-A.review_text: Chose Capps at random as it was near Beach Blanket Babylon and looked like a cool old-style place. It was OK, but next time in North Beach I will definitely try somewhere else.  Porkchop in Mushroom sauce - the sauce was the best part! While it was a full bone-in chop, overcooked for my taste and a bit tough.  Minestrone was great! think and not as tomato-ey as some can be.  Salad nothing special with iceburg lettuse and canned beets.  Dining partner had petrole sole - tasty yet swimming in butter.   Perhaps if we had ordered an Italian staple like ravoli or lagagna we would have had a better experience. I did like the red sauce on my side pasta.  Noise level very high, seating is crowded and waiters are a little gruff.  If that's the ambience they are going for, good job!

_BHTC7nyCBoZcfiiD5cOXg.review_text: This is typical of a dozen or so family-style restaurants that proliferated in this area for years, although most of them have been replaced by upscale bistros that cater to more contemporary tastes. Capp's, on the other hand, probably will be here forever, no doubt with the same original decor of a generation or two ago. This popular restaurant reeks of San Francisco history, its walls covered with fading autographed photos of old-time celebrities, including hometown hero Joe DiMaggio and Marilyn Monroe, who were regulars here. This is not a place for anyone in search of gourmet dining or nouvelle cuisine. The food here is hearty, wholesome Italian fare like Nana used to make every Sunday afternoon. Most popular are the $17 dinners, which include a huge tureen of decent minestrone, a salad bowl overflowing with crisp greens, beans, and beets slathered with a creamy Italian dressing, and pasta marinara and sauteed vegetables accompanying your choice of entree. Selections include calamari steak, osso bucco, baked eggplant, sausage with roasted bell peppers and onions, roasted pork loin, and roast leg of lamb, nicely pink and succulent. The $15 menu includes the soup and salad, but entrees are limited to various pastas. Fresh, doughy Italian bread is perfect for dipping into the soup or sopping up the nicely spiced sauces. Service at times can border on being insufferably rude. One suspects that the older servers here have been standing on their feet so long that their temperaments are permanently crabby. An ideal spot for families and groups. Sophisticated foodies definitely should dine elsewhere.

5ZpL7gDK75N_-9k2x4Qh0w.review_text: Came here as part of a large (and boisterous) group over the weekend. Our server, Sherry, was very sweet and very QUICK!   Onto the important stuff - the wine list is very....ehhhh. The glasses are very affordable, but don't expect any sparks, even by the bottle.   Food: You start with a huge vat of minestrone soup for the table. It's delicious. Hands down the best part of the meal. The salad...ehhh. It's drenched in dressing that is very thick and cloying. Entrees: They are all over the map: I had simply fettuccine noodles with pesto. The pesto itself was good, but the noodles were a bit overdone, and subsequently settled in my stomach much like a brick would. My BFF had the marinara pasta, and she cleaned her plate. Another friend had the pork chops, which she had three bites of and said, "no." Just to round it out, another friend had the seafood pasta, which she announced as one of the best dishes she had had recently.   So, there you have it. It's all over the map. The atmosphere is rockin' in here, and you can tell it's a San Francisco tradition. It's worth a visit just to say you've been to Capps, and the prices are extremely reasonable.

elmJhxmQdwJtKy8y-PL-2w.review_text: Alright, there is one reviewer who hit it, you don't go to Capp's Corner for the food if you expect some outlandish culinary experience, just walking in the door should tell you this.  Your plate will not be sprinkled with dots of pretentious sauce.  It is a family place serving food that most of us can make at home -- this is its appeal, because we don't want to cook.  On the other hand, you can get lucky and get a really fine meal.  People like Gloria don't seem to get it.  BBB has been good for this place and so was Keystone Korner, the jazz place next to the police station that no longer exists.  I tell my kids that they will probably not be able to take their kids to Capp's because I don't know how long it can hold out with the suburbanization of North Beach and the influx of people who have no aesthetic sense.  If it was good enough for Herb Cain, it is good enough for the rest of us.  Have been going here since the '60s and have been in dozens of other places in the city that serve better food, but why is it that I come back?  Can't put my finger on it but I love it.

eWoW5HucSzs4G3UTSi2z4A.review_text: What a great time we had Saturday night at Capp's Corner. Located in North Beach, we took 7 adults and 7 girls for a late night dinner at 8:30.  The minestrone soup served before our meal was so tasty and all our meals were wonderful. I had a steak that was so large I was able to let my daughter have more than half!  The waiter and bartender were fantastic. They even hailed cabs for us (we needed 4) at 11:30.   We tried all sorts of food, most people had pasta and they raved about the ravioli.   I highly recommend Capps.

TZExGajxC02oetl7iQ77eg.review_text:
Horrible experience...  I got  very sick within 20-30 minutes of eating the soup/salad course, and before the entree arrived I was in the bathroom for a half hour ... and then they had the nerve to charge us for my dinner.  Adding insult to injury, I had not even touched the main course, but they insisted we pay for the whole dinner because "you ordered it already".... unbelievable.  I refused to pay but my date paid while I went back in the can to get sick again.  The waitron seemed to imply to my date that i was either "already sick when I got there" or bulimic... so  insulting.  I was neither sick before walking in nor bulimic, but  I was sick the remainder of the evening.
  Even if it was a food allergy (I'm not aware of having any food allergies), or a case of "instant" flu with no other symptoms,  and not something in the food like MSG or some other thing, it seems odd to me that a restaurant would charge for food when the diner immediately experienced extreme gastric distress after eating some of it, whatever the reason, and particularly strange to charge for the entree which wasn't even served prior to the onset of the distress, and certainly was not wanted.  
  Most restaurants allow diners to send back food that's unsatisfactory, for whatever reason, and either replace the dish with something else or, if the diner has lost his or her appetite after sending it back, do not charge for it.  Not here.  
  I called them the next day to complain and they expressed no regrets for how the situation was handled and cut the conversation off.  I found the whole thing unprofessional.

QVAmRIrCxhYLqh7wl4Vlog.review_text: This place has a cool vibe, fast and friendly service, somewhat tasty food, and somewhat high prices.   + The waiter checked on us so many times and was very friendly + Cool art everywhere made for a nice atmosphere + Wait times weren't 't too long + When we ordered soup for 4, they gave us enough for around 5 servings + The garlic bread was cheap and had lots of garlic - Prices were a little steep for the portions - My vegetables were soaked in a huge pond of butter that flowed all over the plate - The chicken parmigiana wasn't crunchy but instead kind of soggy. I have to blame the weird consistency on that pond of butter nearby...  All in all, this place was A-OK.

8VmxAELPm0CKpKrZnS6NKg.review_text: I worked next door to Capp's (at The Blanket) for 3 and half years, and during those 3 and a half years, I spent just as much time at Capp's as I did backstage, rarely sampling the cuisine. I can tell you some things about drinking at Capp's, though. Boy, can I.  There was a time when the late, great, legendary bartender Neil would see me walking towards the front door and by the time my ass hit a barstool, a "Beth-size vodka tonic with a shit load of lime" would be on the counter. Neil has since passed away, his photo framed in the corner reminding me of so many happy memories, or lack there of.  Whenever I'm in North Beach, I still swing by Capp's, saying hi to old friends from the Blanket, throwing a wink to the photo of Neil and reminiscing about my drunken, New Year's rendition of Rapper's Delight, a bottle of champagne in one hand and a microphone in the other. Good times...

bgUmuR8ZuLe_nFUVHXLGSA.review_text: It was years since I was there, and I just went tonight, and oh my - not good.  Perhaps if you really don't care decent food or service - sure - go - have at it.  Why did I go? We had a big group. Now they're all mad at me.

xbDuLijIrSV9Tw_x2al09g.review_text: It seems like everyone has said it before, this place is an institution.  Everything is amazing, but the best is the Veal Tortellini!  You feel the guilt as you order it, but the second you taste it, it all goes out the window.  So yummy and it feels like family here.   Great old school family style Italian food.  Their minestrone alone  is worth the trip.

tGju_rBrS8UXBQxbpjukcg.review_text: I was really looking forward to experiencing this restaurant again, but never got the chance due to their minimum order per person.  Our family was trapped in SF after a huge traffic snarl, so we decided to have dinner in North Beach.  We ordered wine, kids had Shirley Temples and appetizer order was placed, much to the delight of the waitress.  The fun didn't start until we said the kids wanted to split a meal.  Each person needed to have a minimum "FOOD" order and drinks, appetizers and other people's order don't count.  I explained to the waitress that we're stuck waiting for traffic to dissipate and we just got done with a tour of SF ice creameries.  No effect.  Her statement was "rules are that everyone needs an entree."   We walked out.

lNSkba_B8yrvpEuHAi7mXw.review_text: Love the feel of this place.  Fun place to eat or drink.  The spaghetti and meatballs are tasty, the front bar is casual, it is always easy to carry a conversation and the whole experience is just laid back.  I will definitely keep coming here.

X3zMBh3SLgvrXaRtZ9JthA.review_text: They fired the best bartender I have ever known and I will never go back there again.  Luckily he's working down the street now- and THAT bar will get all my business from now on.

7SkJ2HcwqTNURER7-lvJ0A.review_text: A really good classic old North Beach restaurant.  Great Italian food.  Three course meal with soup and salad. Close to Beach Blanket Babaylon too.  Nice to take a walk around North Beach afterward.  If you have room, it's fun to walk over to the gelato place for desert and around Washington Square or up to Coit Tower.  Fun to bring out-of-town visitors here.

OK5B_PHxTDlLfhmIV2MxPw.review_text: Capp's Corner is basically a family style, neighborhood Italian restaurant and bar. Great atmosphere... a little dark, wood paneling, red & white checker board accented tables, with lots of pictures of legendary and local celebrities. Place has been around since 1960. Very friendly service from greeting to good-byes. Excellent efforts to be accommodating and make you comfortable. At the bar, well drinks and wine by the glass are around $4.  We had dinner here for wifey's b-day. There were five of us, so there was lots of sampling going on. What we ordered was very good. They must've had their first stringers in the kitchen this night. I ordered the calamari steak with caper sauce. It was so tender and flavorful. Wife had the Veal Milanese, breaded also with caper sauce. She said it was the best, and I had to agree. I also tasted the tortellini, just awesome with a creamy yet light tomato sauce. Grand daughter ordered Veg Fettuccine. It was piled in her plate. Get this, she expected Alfredo sauce which wasn't on the menu, but the waiter took it back and had it added. How cool was that?  So where's the fifth star? The soup tureen was taken with soup still in it, and the salad was a too plain, just not enough stuff... not even any tomatoes or olives or peppers. AND the only dessert is ice cream. No pies, no canoli... not even any tiramisu. Funny thing, the host (great guy, been there forever), when we asked about canoli, laughingly told us to hit Cafe Roma's, a block away.  Capp's Corner is cool, fun... GREAT FOOD. Check it out!

k7AOqQE4mpaQ1UseR1RIlg.review_text: Really friendly staff and humorous server.  Order came quick. Minestroni soup and a good salad (better than your average Olive Garden) to share while you wait for your entrée.

YPkXV7QgbUR7S7tnfAtI_Q.review_text: Let's start at zero stars.  I found the menu and ordering system to be totally misleading and if you aren't that hungry, you're basically screwed because if you sit down, they make you order an entree.  No sharing of entrees, come on!   Minus one star.  To compensate and continue the myth of dining "family style", they bring you a loaf of fresh, crusty Italian bread (yum), a big bowl of minestrone (yuck for me, although my dining companions enjoyed it), and a big bowl of dubious lettuce smothered in beets, beans and too much dressing (ok, but not really for me).  Minus one star.  The entrees themselves, however, were delicious.  I had the veal tortellini and they were melt-in-your-mouth baby cowy goodness in a tomato cream sauce which was to die for and matched perfectly.  My dining companions had the cheese ravioli and the calamari linguine.  I didn't try the ravioli, but Companion #1 enjoyed it very much.  I did try the calamari linguine and it wasn't bad.  Companion #2 ate it pretty happily.  That's three good entrees.  Plus three stars.  The surliness of the waitress, the kitschy decor and the broad variety of clientele added to the charm.  You will not find yuppies and douchebags here, so let's add another two.  And here we are.  Three solid stars.  I recommend it, but you gotta know that their "family style" is a myth and you will be made to order; come hungry!

aUbpxUZSdZ9qWU6Hz4_dYg.review_text: Good solid home-style Italian food.  I've never had a bad meal at Capp's.  It reminds me of the old school neighborhood Italian restaurants you would find.  Drink and food prices are reasonable.  Portions are more than enough.  Their minestrone is really good.  Everything is served family style.  The decor is very kitsch with old photos.  if you're looking for a fancy Italian dinner, this isn't the place for you.  but if you're looking for good Spaghetti and Meatballs and Cannelloni, Salad, and Soup, then it's perfect.

z-kyHYF6oUad7inUVG0Mzw.review_text: Good place, but a little low key for me.

sAXAyCi1q4zpEAhqugT0Xg.review_text: I love this place. All the photos on the wall, the checkerboard tablecloths, the noise level: just perfect for North Beach. A great place to bring some out of town guests before you take them to see Beach Blanket Babylon down the street at Club Fugazi. Or, in my case, drop them off at Club Fugazi, since I've seen the show several times. I especially like the way they serve the salad and the minestrone soup family style. Even my kids loved it, because they could be noisy and a little messy, and nobody even blinked an eye. A lovely, boisterous San Francisco landmark. The only reason I'm giving four stars instead of five, is the men's restroom is so cramped, and the urinal is right next to the sink, I mean right next to it. Just move the elimination porcelain a little ways from the washing porcelain, and I will add one more star. Oh well, I suppose it's all part of the "charm."  Still, I love Capp's Corner!

e1FuiYSV1v29q2OTR9ojBA.review_text: Holy crap.  Best bar ever after BBB gets out and the front of house staff (and occasional cast member) comes to have a drink.  Thanks to our friend (a server at BBB and a Capp's regular), we got the royal treatment at the bar.  (I won't go into details because I think you just have to go and check it out for yourself.)  Regarding the restaurant portion, I've had the food and it's only okay.  I do love the "Old North Beach" vibe about the place, with all the celebrity photos on the walls.  Capp's is kind of a NB institution...and I respect that.  Four solid stars with room for improvement.

0ZG8CwVOFFYrUdybrNzNOw.review_text: A family-style Italian restaurant with modest prices and large portions, this little eatery is a good place to come if you don't want to pay too much and you just want some simple, straightforward pasta.  A tureen of soup, a huge bowl of salad, and baskets of bread come with whatever meal you order.  Hint: tell them to put the salad dressing on the side, or you will get far more than you desire.  The atmosphere has a vintage, neighborhood feel.  The servers are all friendly and hard working.  Nothing fancy here.  Nothing fabulous.  But for a quick place to just sit down with your friends, eat, laugh, drink, and relax, Capp's Corner works.

EjVRsZhNyG7vkCxVci7xHQ.review_text: Capp's is a nice change of pace. I recently have been so obsessed with new American and fusion spots I forgot what fun a traditional family oriented restaurant can be.  Capp's is a family style restaurant with pre-set menus where you can pick your entree and soup, salad and bread are included in the price (about $18-21). They have nightly specials, but were sadly out of clams when we arrived for our 8pm dinner reservation. I had the pesto linguini and the pesto was average (and abnormally green, artificial looking).  The servers are totally nice and the decor is standard old-school Italian with red-checked tables, white porcelain plates and a wooden bar. The food is okay, nothing artsy or anything that will shock you, but okay. This type of place is more about the ambiance than the food.   My Tips: - You should know the minestrone soup is not vegetarian it's made with chicken broth - The wine is not good, but corkage fee is only $10 so bring your own - Don't skip the salad, it is delicious - Entrees mostly consist of pasta dishes so make sure you are in the mood for something substantial  I am pretty picky so family style isn't always the best for me, but the experience was enjoyable.

yshuPf-UY_YUdXrfrGUUgA.review_text: If you're hungry and want amazing food and service-- come here!!   They feed you Italian family style, which means they have to roll you out of the establishment. You will start with soup and salad, with an amazing olive oil and bread for dipping. I went with the spaghetti and meatballs for roughly ~18.00 (pre-tax and tip) and the man candy went with chicken parm.  Pros: Great service Amazing food Good portions   Cons: Carbs= calories

ySnJRrXNpbHuGYsm5mEAVA.review_text: Haven't eaten here yet but they have a great bar seen later in the evening. Take a moment to talk to the bartender, hang out with the kids from the show next door and bypass all the ridiculousness of Columbus Street. Good times.

-_dGQOHpKRFgDy5yTjjlUQ.review_text: I agree with the other reviewers that Capp's has that great family-style appeal.  The prices are reasonable and the portions are fairly generous.  I came with a large group and the waitress was really impatient and rude from the very start.  The attitude was completely unnecessary.  I was really disappointed by the experience and would not go back.

Xv0Kts_5qDIG6WUC2-646A.review_text: I know it's been three years since I promised to update "next month" but, what the hey my opinion has not changed that much except that I'm liking it better.  Since my original review, I've been here ten (probably more) times.  The atmosphere is unpretentious.  The service is great and personable, the minestroni is tasty and the salad, while not fancy, is perfect for my taste.  I've had a variety of entres and they're all wonderful.  Of course since you eat family style the quality of the salad may just depend on who in your group is the best at "salad tossing."  Capp's Corner is Cozy and Comfty and is now a regular stop on my itinerary.  I know that parking can be difficult in North Beach but not at all impossible.

RxBmMXaOdkPbj5wUT5-AWQ.review_text: Absolute garbage. Food on a plane is better. Do yourself a favor and go anywhere else. Yuck!

6ELIw3Kpgh1SAXJoGkf6hA.review_text: We went with a large group on 12/22/12 and had a great time. The food was good and the service ok. We were though a little rushed. Loved the soup and salad. Definitely will be coming back!

Ygs2NRPXd8S7_pa9jfOpHQ.review_text: Are you kidding me?  I guess it is "the place" to eat before or after seeing Beach Blanket Babylon but we won't be back.  The noise was outrageous and we were crowded by very large customers sitting right behind us.  The 'family style' dining means they bring each table a big bowl of minestrone soup that is so bland it tastes like it's been sitting all day.  The big bowl of salad was good - tons of dressing but typical of what you would get in the 60's and I suppose that is what they are going for - the "pre-foodie" type of food.  The food was mediocre at best and there was no real 'ambiance.'

k6kMHSAgbwVvneM5ukfJUg.review_text: Minestrone was decent, salad had beets but no tomatoes (yuck), vegetables were mushy (overcooked perhaps), lasagne was about the same quality as a high school cafeteria. The spumoni was a pleasant treat though!

xpRAjmgL-pIcIY_9iOpcQw.review_text: While I've had my share of cocktails here, until recently,  I had never tried the food.  I must say that I was very pleasantly surprised.  The minestrone was pretty  good and thickened with flour just like my nana's.  The salad was nothing to get excited about, but hell it was salad...I never get excited about salad.  I'd highly recommend the fettucine and clams with white wine sauce...I tend to get that a lot in sketchy italian places because assuming the clams aren't bad it's pretty hard to screw up.  Capp's did them well.  The real surprise was the Osso Buco.  It's probably my favorite I talian dish and I'm generally disappointed, but Capp's sauce was perfect and the meat disintegrated when touched with a fork.  Not the best I've had but damn tasty.  And we were out the door for $42 including tip.  "Quaint" is a good euphemism for the atmosphere/decor, but it really is authentic.  I've had plastic utensils with more heft than the steak knife they gave me, and the house wines are Inglenook...shudder.  We ate late and the owner was at the table next to us totalling up the night's receipts in pencil in one of those black speckled composition books.  I'm a total sucker for crap like that.

Eaoo4Bh72FSjSxeGNIad7g.review_text: Looking forward to visiting Capp's on Sept. 21 when my cruise ship docks. Whenever I'm in The City, I always stop by. The great thing is: it never changes. The ambiance is always there. Good food and drinks and the staff is very friendly. Ran into Margo St. James there on one of my visits. You never know who might be sitting next to you at the bar.

nlOxarS20luHkAloH5YyzA.review_text: I really don't understand why so many people gave this place a good review.  I can't even describe how disgusting the food is here.  First they brought us soup and salad.  The soup was a minestrone and very, very bland.  I had to add a ton of salt and pepper just to get it down.  The salad reminded me of something you'd buy pre-made at the grocery store.  Since I don't eat pasta, which might be my problem with this place, I ordered a steak.  There really wasn't much of anything else on the menu that I could eat.  Weirdly, the steak comes with a side of pasta, but I opted out of that since there is no way I'd eat it.  Now, I don't really consider myself that picky of an eater.  I usually eat everything and think most stuff is pretty good.  But the food here was just wretched.  The steak was first off gross looking.  You'd think presentation would count for something, but a hotdog looked more appetizing than this.  But sometimes stuff looks gross and tastes good.  Well, not in the case.  The steak was quite tough and had random chunks of fat in it.  Anyway, my entire meal was just really, really bad.  So I basically never want to go back.

xKGwVnamNpdZAdzoN-_5Hw.review_text: This place is so delicious! If you miss Caesar's in SF then this place is the place to go. They do family style courses, which is my favorite! So each dish comes with soup and salad that they serve family style and then you get your main dish served individually. I got the linguine with clams and mussels which was amazing. That is my usual go to dish at Italian restaurants and this one was by fair the best I have had. This restaurant, though small, works wonderfully with groups. We had I believe 20 of us and they worked us in perfectly. Service is great, though the bartender seemed to be in a bad mood. All in all, fantastic food. I can't wait to go back.

YMkkjYuojBf-uOh9atGUiQ.review_text: Closest to New York Italian in San Francisco. Great atmosphere and super prices.

djDpJMnZyLvgG1VGf65PiA.review_text: Definitely old San Francisco.  Many of the great family style places with great food and great value in North Beach are gone, but Capp's continues the tradition.  It feels like home.  The veal milanese is fantastic, and is my favorite.  Also expecially fond of the Osso-Bucco (and that's a dish you hardly find in North Beach anymore, though it used to be a staple of family owned places).  The staff are great, and the price is right.  They could use some new chairs, but otherwise it is a great place for the real thing.

oZ4zwTAR2C9kGUL2aCGccQ.review_text: Was here on April 21st, what happened?  The attendant recommended the Lamb Shank plate. My friends had the fresh sea bass and they loved it!  One of the best things about Capps, is when you order the plate dinner it includes a generous supply of soup and salad. Both did not disappoint.  However, when my meal arrived, it looked good and all, but the lamb shank meat tasted as if it was cooked a few days ago. One or two days old would have been reasonable, but my lamb shank tasted reheated a few too many times. C'mon Capps : up your game!  Four people = $165.00 not cheap.  I might go back again.  Customer service: fine.  I have been here more than ten times.

pRQ3cXfNaNsYfN7-ElCpvg.review_text: Capps Place is Awesome. Visiting from out of town, my girlfriend and I stumbled in after a walk up and down the hills of SF looking for beer and a bathroom. Just opening Jack and the crew welcomed us right in where we took a seat at the bar.   Anchorsteam and a Champagne Split. Perfect combo for the warm San Francisco day. We chatted it up with the Jack manning the bar and Eddie a local.  It always a great feeling be able to walk into a random bar or restaurant and feel instantly at home.

4kfTglFC5RBcZsXOX6d5vw.review_text: came for a friends bday the other night and was impressed!! me likey! small and homey, great service, decently priced and tasty!  vodka tonic was strong, bread was cold: meh, wine was cheap, clam chowder was good!, salad: meh (even tho i appreciated the beets, kidney & garbanzo beans), linguini with pesto also really good! the servers were really friendly and location is primo for hitting up the bars afterwards...the only downer with that is i couldnt shove my huge plate of linguini leftovers in my clutch or carry around a bag of pasta so that i could have it the next day      :-/  this is a great place to take visitors and also great for groups! do it!

tLz1zvn81gGXIkbrcNtdgQ.review_text: Came here after Beach Blanket Babylon and  it was just okay for me. The service we had was absolutely five stars! Show ended around 6:40 and we had a reservation for a large party at 7, but they had our table ready early. Our waiter was always refilling drinks, asking how the food was and taking our plates just in time for the next meal. The family style part of the meal is soup and salad, both of which I thought tasted delicious! First time in a while I've had beets in a regular salad. I do wish it didn't come drenched in so much dressing, but I still enjoyed it. The entrees were mediocre IMO. I got the chicken parmigiana and it comes with a little bit of pasta with marinara and veggies. My fiance got the pork chop and I think that tasted a little better, especially being with the mushrooms! Overall the place was okay, and I would return if I needed something close to the area. Service - 5 stars, food - 3 stars, location - 4 stars with easy parking (in the parking garage) and close to the show.

XJhmTEAJuYRgIP4b9wMcTw.review_text: It's rare that I find a bartender who *demands* a tip, just as I'm pulling out my wallet to give him one...  Needless to say, I paused mid-wallet-pull, finished my drink, and walked out the door.

qMPnrqWXFVDJTVhQwqJHaw.review_text: Overpriced, but good enough. The soup and salad are good. I had some pesto which was very nice and flavorful, but like I said, the place is definitely overpriced for its entrees. But the wine is cheap :)

pbWRfIpJGPxImGFpEy8zsA.review_text: Used to be great. Last time it was far to busy and the service suffered greatly.

ss1PGLjfjitXP2o0_95SCA.review_text: I like it.  It's just a quaint bar with a very New York feel. Sometimes there are a lot of Bridge and Tunnel going to BBB but well, what can you do!  No offense Bridge and Tunnelers but you do stick out quite like the tourists.  Ouch!  Don't be hatin' now!

wVpwTZ0ynSgHWn_tgzx2vg.review_text: I always wanted to have a family-style dinner at Capps.  I frequent the neighboring pubs on the block and always see Capps packed to the rafters.  I got a really good feeling from this place when they let me use their restroom (sad but true) during North Beach Fest when every other place turned me down.    I was a little disappointed by their definition of "family style."  This holiday season I've been eating like it's going out of style, and I was looking forward to "pick-and-choose" smaller portions of a shared meal.  The only part of the meal that comes family style in the vat of minnestrone soup (delish!) and the salad (would be better if it wasn't postively drenched in dressing).    The entrees range from $18 (pastas) to $20 (chicken, pork, eggplant parm, etc).  Portions are hefty!  I had the Seafood Linguine special with red sauce, which was exactly what I was in the mood for:  shellfish, calamari and perfectly-prepared flat noodles swimming in a garlicy sea of tomato.  Mmmmm, perfection.  This same dish with the white sauce was reportedly buttery.   The pinot noir tasted like altar wine from my Catholic school days.  The pork chop was reportedly dry.  The spaghetti and meatballs is huge!  In no way will you leave hungry!  Capps is ideal for big groups, and you can tell by all the smiles, roars of laughter and the clinking of glasses between generations that families are having a great time.  At the end of the day, that is the whole point.  Capps in no-frills dining with its checkered table clothes, old North Beach neighborhood photographs which grace the walls, and the over-extended servers who will take your order, give you what you need, but no more than that.    Bring Uncle Mike, Cousin Ann, Grandma Kay, and even maybe that finnicky Aunt Marion...but maybe choose a different venue for date night with your significant other.

KLc0yiHGlmGYWB4NOpOUQQ.review_text: My friends and I were looking for a nice Italian place to eat at before Beach Blanket Babylon and we thought this place might be good. When we first walked in, the place had a really weird smell but I chose to ignore it and see what was on the menu. After seeing the very little variety they had to offer, I placed my order to the very unfriendly waitress who was very short with us. She served us soup and salad and removed the bowls from the table while we were still eating them. There was still food in the bowls!! She did this without saying more than two words to us. After eating the mediocre soup and salad our main courses arrived. I honestly believe chef boyardee and Kraft can make better Italian food. Finally the rude waitress dropped off the check without saying one word. The check had a sneaky extra $10 charged. After having her remove the "mistake" we left.  I have no personal agenda in writing this review. I just wanted to share my experience and say I will never eat here again.

7kmlaGMjjCHN8rL8oncz_A.review_text: pay attention, that's how you do it ....

DeH52RxnApSENsojBaWomg.review_text: I wouldn't go there again...ever.. I had lamb and they gave me tiny stingy portions and the soup and salad was poor quality. Not even a tomato in my salad. Don't waste your time and money. Go somewhere else like Gaspare's on Geary. I still miss Original Joes.. too bad that it burned down!  Waiter was nice and very attentive though..... great service and nice decor Capps.. Maybe it was a bad cook working thar day who knows... Just my 2 cents.

cZddOgL-F_qm1s2LzRJO8A.review_text: This is the only Italian restaurant my Dad respects! He insists on coming here and he tells me this place has been around for a long time--he used to come here when he lived in the city--now you know THAT'S old. My Dad's best friend happens to be Italian, and he swears by this place. I haven't been here in over a year, but i do have to warn people: This is an AUTHENTIC Italian restaurant. Italian cuisine is very light, robust, and rustic. It is not heavy nor rich, like so many chain restaurants have made it. Though I enjoy my fair share of cheesy, creamy alfredo, my skinny jeans probably prefer the lighter stuff.   This is where Capp's Corner comes in. Friendly service, cute kitschy decor (makes me think Michael Corleone is going to come out and bust a cap in my ass--I loves it!), and all around good food. I usually order the linguine with the mussels (I love mussels...and muscles) which is fantastic. I always have leftovers for a yummy lunch the next day. Flavorful yet didn't feel heavy--Wonderful!  I once ordered the chicken parm and it was a little too overdone for my taste--I don't recommend this here. Their soup and bread were great as well.   Final Verdict: For authentic Italian food in the Bay Area, Capp's Corner is the place to go, Come for the food, stay for the decor, that in itself is one helluva show. Really good food at a very fair price, in this economy, that sounds very nice.

-_mQDj52lVub7xIhAWqiJg.review_text: When I can't possibly take sissy Italian food anymore (sorry Pasta Pomodoro; there's only so much of you I can eat) I make the effort to drive out to the city and eat real, wholesome, classic food. I've only ever come with large groups (family twice, friends once) and it's perfect. There are two pricing levels of entrées; each come with family-style minestrone (delicioussssss) and salad (mmmm). Of course with it all you get scrumptious bread and butter with olive oil to nosh on.  Yummy, simple and old school Italian. What more can you ask for?

y34g-mvZ74Qad_B5FQbboQ.review_text: Here's a small corner spot in North Beach with some real character. The food is great and so is the service. I had eggplant Parmesan and soup. Some of the best minestrone I've had. finish off this great meal with the very best spumoni I have ever put in my mouth.

-PWwpgh0WQFE63KIzyqmKg.review_text: I'd heard about Capp's Corner and decided to eat there after seeing Beach Blanket Babylon. I'd heard from many others that it was a great place and right next door to the play so we went.  To be sure, it was old-style San Francisco dining complete with a ZERO personality grumpy waiter.  "Can we get a smile, please?"  I thought I was eating in a cafeteria served by a guy who hated his job.  Not even a "Welcome to Capp's Corner" let a lone a "My name is Luigi, I will be your server."  OK, I'll admit I'm a bit spoiled. My first advertising job was for a restaurant and I ate at the owners table for dinner weekly, so I got used to a certain level of service.  But isn't that how you're supposed to feel when you are going to a restaurant, that you're with the owner and he wants everything to be right?  As for the food, well, my mom like her meal but the rest of us food snobs barely finished our plates as there just wan't anything special about the entree.  The sautéed vegetable were good.  That was about it.  ONE NOTE.  The bus boy was good and very attentive at pouring our water and cleaning our table.  Too bad he was not serving us, I would have left a bigger tip....

uf-KD798LVjlgeif1KRrUA.review_text: Not a bad place to eat if you're really hungry.    My family and I went there after having mass at Sts. Peter and Paul Church.  Capp's Corner is located in North Beach that borders Chinatown.  The Minnestrone soup was served family style; the flavor was good, but it appears the soup has been sitting in the pot for days!  I can't make out what vegetables or ingredients were in my bowl ;(  The entire meal was acceptable and portions were adequate.  The server was warm and friendly initally, but developed a little attitude towards the end of our meal.  He actually brought to our attention what his gratuities should be and took the liberty to make the necessary adjustments.  Capp's Corner reminds me of a friendly and warm SF local neighborhood drinking establishment back in the good ol' days.

ZtmeHAQyNFku338dJMIfTg.review_text: I always tell people.. skip the Stinking Rose, Panta Rei and Calzone's... the places that give North Beach a bad name... and walk yourself one block off Columbus in ANY direction.. and you're bound to find a good Italian restaurant. Sodini's, Contandina, Bocce...  And Capp's...  It's a bit touristy because it's right near BBB but that's ok because it's basic and authentic.  I love the random decor, especially the red and white plaid picnic-looking table tops.  I had the spaghetti and meatballs and I have a feeling it's going to become a new crave.  This place is not fancy.
