It's simple, friendly, tasty Italian.  It is very family friendly so it's probably not a good date place. Go with friends or family for a casual dinner.

4YK8H4Bu_qoGO6latjaqgA.review_text: I eat here regularly for the last 20 years or more. I am meeting my relatives here tonight. Hope it is as good as usual. I love the laid back feeling of it.

iTXymihtdXLvYbTxVtVjNw.review_text: Delicious, family style Italian food. My husband and I were meeting some friends for dinner and weren't sure if we were at the right place. I guess the staff noticed our lost look because they immediately came outside to ask if we were the couple - with the baby - that was part of the group of four. They brought us inside, seated us immediately, asked about a high chair and took an order for my daughter (who is only a year old). Service gets five stars from me. I felt right at home.   Being a family style restaurant, all meals come with soup and salad. The minestrone was good, but I didn't have the salad (aversion to creamy dressings). As a table we ordered mussels, lasagne, veal tortellini and canneloni. Everything was delicious. We were all incredibly pleased with the meal (and the service!). I'd say my only comment is that the plate of tortellini lacked presentation. The pasta was just kind of dumped on the plate and smothered in sauce - no cheese, no basil, no veggies...the sauce was amazing, though.   Definitely coming back!!

2cEh0prIgpGMDjBRvVykFw.review_text: Like several have said, Capp's is a SF/NB institution. I'm not sure how we found this place, maybe while on a N Beach walking tour, or maybe drove by coming from the theater. But, none the less, so grateful a find. It's basic, its unassuming, it's old world SF, and it's great food, elite service and they run it like a nickle balanced on edge. Nothing ever seems to go wrong, although, like any place that serves to please people, I'm sure this is not true,  The minestrone and salad is what keeps us coming back, and I'm not a soup/salad person. But the entrees, although not remarkable, are equally delicious. Just GREAT basic Italian/American fare. It's one of those, you know what to expect, service, food and wait wise places, and they never disappoint. Good spumoni too.

Q894BDSToSiwhMRWYDCYRw.review_text: We stopped in right before dinner service ended. Not only was the service friendly and quick,  but the food was incredible. The atmosphere was welcoming and we had a great time. We usually like to jump around to different places, but we'll definitely be returning here soon!

NkVYcoaThHjOfTTgq6OdHQ.review_text: i love capps! usually always packed and thats because of 2 things.... all the people going to see BBB next door come here, and also because the food is good. service is even pretty good despite it always being so busy.

0XXIv9a0LWiaCjAkurjMMQ.review_text: The soul of North Beach is alive and well.    Thirty or forty years ago any number of restaurants along Columbus Avenue competed for customers, serving prix fixe dinners, all with about the same menu, "family style."  Most have gone, but Capp's is going strong.    We arrived at 5 pm on Saturday, and nearly had the whole place to ourselves.  Walking inside, we noticed the bar next to the front door, conveniently placed so customers could wait in comfort on busy nights.  The hostess on the right, at her podium, where she has probably been stationed every night since 1945.  The long tables, where people were seated next to each other, without regard to personal space.  That's family style.    We had a choice of entrees.  Margaret chose lamb, and I went for the hot Italian sausage and peppers.  The opening course was minestrone soup, the exact same recipe that has been served all over North Beach.  Then a salad, with the beets, kidney beans, and garbanzos.  Penne pasta with a Tuscan marinara came on the side of the entree plate -- even some pasta entrees come with a pasta on the side.  One glass of chardonnay, one glass of merlot.  For a perfect Italian finish, we accepted a dish of spumoni ice cream -- they were generous with the chocolate, moderate with the cherry, and not so generous with the pistachio.  Perhaps it was the luck of the scoops.  All of this for $55.50 plus tip.    Midway through our dinner, a party of four arrived to celebrate a birthday.  Their conversation drifted to other birthday dinners they had celebrated at other restaurants.  Reminiscing, being out of the moment, somehow seemed appropriate, for much of North Beach has changed.  But Capp's Corner is still the same.

dw309iAtnodDKeVyeA6pjw.review_text: I was introduced to Capps by The Man years ago, on our first trip to The City together as he'd been coming with his Italian family since he was a kid... since then, this is literally my go to place when in SF.  I come here with him, without him, during the week, on weekends, holidays, whenever i happen to stop in the lovely City by the Bay.  A few things you should know... leave pretense and attitude at the door.... this place is legit.  NO you won't get frou frou small food on a big plate, NO your salad won't come with dressing on the side (maybe it will, never asked because when in Rome...) NO it's not Burger King and you won't get it your way... unless you happen to be charming like my Man who could charm the honey out of a bee... and even he can't have it all the way he wants it... NO they don't have a great dessert selection either, but my god don't you want to go walk around North Beach for that?!  What you will find is a fantastic little corner place that's been there forever, with waitstaff that knows when to approach, when to leave you alone and what to suggest.  The bar has a great selection of basic and not so basic potables for just about every taste and I've never felt overcharged or underfed / underserved in each of the oh... dunno... 25+ times I've been there?  it's kitschy, local, relaxing and filling...the food is always satisfying, and thoughtfully prepared... all high marks in my book.  Next time you go... ask the bartender for a Galliano.... tell em the lady in the Beehive sentcha...  :)

dM9OJJzpM0omMjwIlUBGfQ.review_text: Over the years Chinatown has been slowly expanding into North Beach & the old school Italian restaurants have been slowly dying out as well.  Capt Hook used to go here from his days as a Golden Bear so whenever we hit town Capp's is always on the menu.  The communal tables are dwindling but they still plop down a bowl of minestrone soup as soon as you sit down.  If you come on Friday you get either minestrone or New England style clam chowder or if you give them puppy dog eyes a little of both!  Mmm, creamy clam chowder with cooked down chunks of potato & tender sweet slivers of clam or savory minestrone with tangy tomatoes, starchy beans & veggies.  [gahhh...slurp!]  And then, they bring out a truly yummy salad with pickled beets, chick peas, kidney beans, sunflower seeds & creamy housemade Italian dressing.  So by now, you've definitely bought yourself enough time to figure out what you want, right?  The Osso Buco is classically done--braised veal shank that you can eat with a fork in a tangy tomato sauce & tender diced veggies with polenta & penne alla arabiata on the side.  Definitely satisfies the carnivore within.  I always overeat which causes me problems later in the night but that's what hubbies & tummy rubs are for, no?  The Cannelloni is also a winner with ground veal & ricotta in a pink sauce--creamy, cheesy, & velvety.  Be ready to take home leftovers because it's too rich (in a good way) to finish in one sitting.  Oh & don't forget the specials.  We had a roast half chicken in a marsala mushroom sauce that was so succulent & tender that during our plate rotations (we like to eat family style) it was definitely the belle of the ball.  The clientele is definitely aging & the communal atmosphere is changing over to separate tables--younger diners don't seem to want to rub elbows with strangers & get caught up in fascinating anecdotal tidbits which is a shame.  Hopefully Capp's will still be there for next fall's Berkeley games so Capt Hook & I can overeat ourselves into happy food comas when we're in town.

T9-I5G3KQJoF9od3q7Xvrw.review_text: The best place in the city for Family-style Italian dining. Sit at the beautiful bar, or cozy up with some friends in their comfy dining room. Bring an appetite, or clear out some room in your fridge, because the portions are BIG! The fare is surprisingly affordable for the quality. I brought my parents here who were visiting from the East Coast, and the owner came out and personally welcomed ALL of us. I highly recommend their Italian Sausage dinner...YUMMM!

PKGTuC21BbBFEYzh31u3yg.review_text: The minestrone soup is very good. And they give you lots of bread. I had the chicken parmigiana that was satisfactory. Our food server was very attentive and we were never low on beverages. My friend had the ravioli which she loved!  The location was perfect for dinner before Beach Blanket Babylon :) I would go back for the soup.

ytxm744qKpJ04EK3EF7prw.review_text: It's in North Beach and has been serving for decades.  You're not going to find anything other than a kind of Americanized Italian food, but it's tasty.  I particularly liked the minestrone that comes with dinner along with salad.  The soup had good flavor, was murky (a plus for me) and could be a meal in itself along with the good bread/butter that they served.  I had the calamari steak dore' which I enjoyed.  I also tasted the fettuccine with prawns and I liked the flavor, but the prawns were cooked too much so they were a little tough.  It's not fancy and it's loud when the bar fills up, but it satisfies when you're looking for something that's good and inexpensive (soup, bread, salad, entree', ice cream is 20 bucks)   Andiamo!

UhN9RrW19vz7vFWgWVLn_w.review_text: Boy has this gone down hill. The worst minnestroni soup I ever had. Taste like left over lental soup. Very bland. Capps What happened????

1ljC2JgUafYC9wtEUXJ3bQ.review_text: Came here with one of my law school professors, who had been coming here for the past 15 years.  The first thing you'll notice about Capp's is that everyone here is, "like," really old.  Capp's has been around forever, which means you'll see people like the owner of City Lights or Mayor Ed Lee's friends.  Seriously, though.  Around noon on Fridays, there will sometimes be group of 20+ old senior men sitting at a table... they have frequent reunions!  Adorable.  All the food tastes homemade, so the flavor won't be super intense or MSG-y.  Everything is rather mild, which I prefer... because I'd like to think that it's kind of healthy.    For lunch, if you like seafood, I recommend the filet of sole (the lemon butter flat fish).  It's $14, and comes with a side of veggies, pasta and your choice between soup or salad.  One guy in our group got a little less pasta, so we notified the waiter, who just brought out a brand new bowl of pasta for him - no questions asked.  My other friends also ordered the cannelloni, but the filet of sole was definitely the most ordered / most popular item in our group.   Don't forget to top off your meal with some spumoni, either (:  That way you'll get the full North Beach / Little Italy experience!  ALSO there's a full bar.

9wJQDStmRRabC5Yx978peQ.review_text: Before being offered dessert we were offered the check.  Despite that, I requested dessert to the waiter's disappointment.  He gave us the dessert free but then explained he wanted us to pay the check immediately so he could go home right away.  And that's too bad because the family style food was good.

fGpQET0VduXx4lbDSBCgtA.review_text: The food is good, but they advertise themselves as "family style" yet when you share a plate they charge you $10 extra!  I do not know what they mean by family style then as every other place I've been to that is family style serves you an order in a big bowl meant to share with 2-3 people.   In any case, the soup was fantastic! Got the lasagna and it was ok.

JzmJ6U20uJ9pZonwKGvMuA.review_text: I'll forgo my usual verbose review and simply say, "GET THE VEAL TORTELLINI IN SUN DRIED TOMATO CREAM SAUCE!!!".  That is all you need to know about this place.  Fellow carb addicts, mangia!!

GCuDiPUKYxhgFHP5LqJa2Q.review_text: 3 stars because of their historical value.  I really doubt people come here for the food - there are plenty within a stone throw away with much better food and likely more service.  Have heard about this place and walked by too many times.  Finally, we decided to try this place since we are running out of place to try in the area.  Maybe because it was a Friday before the show, the place was full when we walked in but it was warm and it felt homey.  The lady took our name and when I asked how long it'll be - she said she doesn't know it can be a long time but it will likely be very soon?!?  She's older and maybe confused...anyway, she suggested sitting at the bar while we wait, not a bad idea.  When the bartender approached us, we told him we were waiting for our table so we would like to look at the wine list.  He asked by the glass or bottle - we said both.  He gave us the menu which included the wine list, both by glass and bottle so not sure why it mattered?    The wine list is very inexpensive - the lowest is $10/bottle and $4/glass.  We decided on a bottle of Montepulciano d'Abruzzo - $16 - think of it as a house red that are served in carafe.  It's light and easy to drink, probably good enough to have w/ the food.  The bartender asked for $ but then said he can add to our dinner tab if we wanted.  We were happy to pay first and leave him a generous tip, he was much friendlier when he saw the tips.  Happy Holidays to you too pal.  We must have waited an hour? before we were sat.  Another 15 minutes before we were a glass of water.  Waited for another 15 minutes and still no bread so I asked hubby to flag someone down.  The waiter and waitress and the busyboys are never to be found and they never give anyone eye contact.  We got the hostess to get us the bread.  When the waitress made it to us, she was apologetic and friendly but still she was mostly a ninja throughout the night.    I can't keep track how long we waited for everything, let's just say a simple dinner took about 3 hours total.  We were not in a hurry but we really can't understand why it took so long for everything.  Except for the entree, everything is readily available.  The bread and butter, the soup and the salad.  The soup and salad were brought to us in a tin bowl, the kind you can find in dollar store  The minestrone was all celery and carrot with one kidney bean and few slices of onion and some Italian herb floating.  The salad was iceberg with canned garbanzo and kidney beans, julienne strips of beets and dressing.    We decided on: linguine w/ clams and mussels in white wine sauce - it was ok, the clams and mussels didn't taste fresh - I do give them credit for serving it piping hot  leg of lamb - there were probably 5 slices of thinly sliced meat.  hubby said only the bottom 2 slices tasted like lamb.  he gives them credit for at least not over cooking it.  it was served with probably 10 pieces of rigatoni in marinara sauce and a spoonful of overcooked mostly carrot and few pieces of zucchini.    Throughout our stay including at the bar - we hear the waiter and waitress asking for drinks to comp customers.  The table of 7 next to us got comp 2 bottles of wine.  When we got our check, we were given a 30% discount because we have been so patient.  While it was appreciated, the amount + more went back to tips.  I will consider this as a SF experience but will not return.

HO9VpfYRzD0QFom85uYNDQ.review_text: Fun, crowded, and crazy.  This San Francisco landmark may not have the best italian food in town, but it sure has the atmosphere.  Go to it with a large party, not a quiet intimate dinner.

SXfbXQQ5_Vgd80aTkjliNQ.review_text: Celebrated John G.'s birthday with him here and it was awesome.  I'm sick and tired of going to expensive, pretentious restaurants for birthday celebrations, and this was really relaxed and laid back.  Our party of 30 showed up half an hour late and no one gave us any grief.  The waitress kept checking to see if we were okay, and refilled our wine at no extra charge.  There was plenty of wine and food for $30 - soup, salad and an entree.    The best part was I put my card down at the bar and then promptly forgot about it.  When I went outside to smoke, the bartender came outside and reminded me not to forget my card, which clearly I had.     I will note, that on a fairly nippy SF night, it was hotter than balls inside the restaurant.  Within moments of stepping inside, we had all removed layers.  Guys were unbutton their shirts, and there were definitely some glistening foreheads.  There were ceiling fans, but they were about as effective as sticking a 5-year old on the ceiling with a paper fan.    Gas rating: 2 Italian food gives me some gas.  So does seeing sweaty men all around me.  So there's your two points on the gas scale.

wfLtwPY91-EYA7wi3xM-pg.review_text: Everyone knows you don't go to Capp's for the food. That said, it's an SF institution with a fun, old school atmosphere. It's family style, so be prepared to sit close to your neighbors, but the portions are big and the prices are fair. It's not that the food is bad, it's just that you can make it yourself, if you feel like it. If you're really hungry and don't feel like cooking, then head to Capp's. Otherwise, save your money and make it at home.

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: So sue me. I like this place. Always have. Always will. Why? It's simple. I'm a pig. A gutless pig. I never order a soup, salad or pasta side dish on top of an entree because I fear the patronizing smirk of a server who gives me the once-over as I hide myself in black because I am under the delusion it's slimming.  Capp's cuts the crap. They give me the soup, the salad, the pasta side dish and enough bread to feed a small French village during the Resistance. No questions. No a la carte nickel-and-diming here. No way. They serve up each item in quick succession. They don't even mess with checkered tablecloths. They just paint the pattern on the formica. Now that's what I call efficient.  So they have a list of $17.50 dinners - all the pasta dishes sized up to be entrees - or you can have one of their $20 dinners - which are the even heartier meat and seafood dishes. Or you could go for one of the two luxury $25 dinners - osso bucco with polenta (really good!...and you'll be stuffed for days) or the grilled NY steak. For real cheapskates, they have the $15 soup/salad/house pasta combo with "house pasta" being code for penne tubes they must order by the ton.  Last night, even after having all those hoity-toity appetizers at Scott Howard during the Yelp Elite event, my friend Carlos and I were still peckish enough to come here. We decided to go for a $15 dinner with penne bathing in the creamiest pesto sauce I ever saw. I've never seen pesto combined with cream before, but hell, who's complaining? And then we decided to split the $20 Chicken Parmigiana dinner. You would think we were bulimic but no. Just two husky guys who don't know when to quit.  The veteran waitress, I'm convinced, can probably serve us with a blindfold on. Here comes the minestrone soup in the dented aluminum bowl. I don't care if the stock predates the arrival of Columbus, it's still the heartiest I've had as it's chock full of chunky veggies. Next comes the salad - which comes in a similar bowl. Iceberg lettuce leaves, tomatoes, cannelloni beans, sliced beets from a can - all of it mixed in a creamy vinaigrette. Reminds me of the school cafeteria. I start to cry 'cause I get all nostalgic.  Ah, here comes the creamy pesto penne and then the man-size serving of chicken parmigiana scorching hot. The side veggies, especially the big chunks of zucchini and carrots - are unbelievably delicious. Must be the stick of butter they obviously use when they heat 'em up.  Full. Uncomfortably full. Too full to go to the men's room in the middle of the restaurant. Capp's Corner never disappoints me. The name always makes me think a one-eyed pirate will come out with a concertina. Ahoy, me mateys. Argh. Maybe it ain't fine dining. But it is about the eating. And who cares? I'm a pig. An unapologetic pig. Go bore someone else with the Zone Diet.  FOOD - 4 stars...a glutton for punishment or a punishment for gluttons...I can't decide because I'm a pig AMBIANCE - 3 stars...North Beach at its Barbary best...hey, if' it's good enough for Marilyn and Joe DiMaggio... SERVICE - 4 stars...like clockwork TOTAL - 4 stars...it's a SF institution...forget Beach Blanket Babylon next door...just eat here to get all the local flavor you want

7JplYGgWFV7EcEHIaQxHpA.review_text: My family and I came here for dinner before Beach Blanket Babylon. As soon as my brother walked up to the Bar, we felt like we had been here 100 times before. The bartender and other waiter who was sitting there made us feel welcome. I was having a low blood sugar attack so I was extremely pleased that we had bread and soup waiting for us as soon as we sat down. Our waitress was sarcastic and funny! My chicken parmigiana was too bready, but I'm used to my dads where he doesn't use any breading. I loved the soup and salad. Everyone else seemed to enjoy their meal.  Would definitely visit again to try something different on the menu.

m9oL5PQ_Sjqpmgqe85qvSA.review_text: Yesterday a friend and I were looking for a place to get a glass of wine or a beer so we could sit and chat before heading home.  Two places we went into in North Beach were  not for us--one was too noisy for conversation and the other too expensive for a glass of wine.  So we went into Capp's and sat at the bar.  Decided to have a beer (Anchor Steam on tap) and asked if they had any appetizers we could order.  Oh, No!  they don't.  but the bartender drummed up cheesy garlic bread and meatballs for us.  Delicious!  And so filling that I realized I was going to call it dinner and just have a bowl of salad when I got home.

DQj7DnJiDV9TAxS0ott-3g.review_text: Really like this place! Been here a few times, both with out-of-town guests as I think it's a good example of a fun, great tasting North Beach eatery. The house wine is pretty decent too-- just one gripe though - the waiters always seem to have very little patience, and don't really wait around if you have to think for a second or two... probably becasue they're so busy, but still - not the friendliest.  But the food speaks for itself...

Om29zM-B9jsEK28m382QWA.review_text: Restaurant half empty at 5:50pm on Sunday night but hostess wants to seat my husband and me at the worst possible table in the house.  (in the back, near the bar and 18 small children.) Allegedly, a large group was due to arrive shortly after us.  Very poorly handled.--take it or leave it mentality.   We didn't stay.  Won't go back.     Guess there is no such thing as customer service anymore.  Please don't patronize this restaurant.

y3HFVx8nbNmomSc-PWOy-g.review_text: Had dinner here Monday night with a friend that was visiting from Italy who remembered this place and wanted to come here.  This place is old school, no doubt about it.  In a lot of ways, it's almost like this place is in a time warp, forever stuck in the 70's, 60's, or worse.  Sadly, this is also true in a culinary sense with the food here as well.  If you are looking for something trendy or sustainable, this is not the place.  However, if you are looking for a charming old school Italian restaurant in SF which is almost exactly the way things used to be (except for prices, LOL), look no further since this place is authentic.  All in all, if you take it for what it is, this place can be a fun and most enjoyable dining experience, especially with good friends.  It's certainly not fancy, but it can be fun.  Lots of old pictures and caricatures on the walls of celebrities over the years gives this place a true old school Italian/SF vibe.  My favorite dish here over the years has always been their osso bucco and like the other night, is what I always order.  Not trendy, but nicely cooked and tender while the sauce had a good depth of flavor.  As always, the dinner came with soup (minestrone), salad (I skipped the salad), and bread.  Years ago, it also included a choice of ice cream, but apparently that has changed.  What happened to the spumoni?  The one expression that keeps coming up over and over is old school.  The quaint little straw bottle chianti that she ordered was the worst wine I have had in recent memory and yet in this environment it all somehow worked.  Perhaps the alcohol from all the wine tastings we did earlier in the evening was a  factor as well.  Afterwards, we bounced around the neighborhood and said hello to all my friends in North Beach.  Definitely a fun night and very Italian or as Italian as you can get in SF.  Bella notte!  Capp's Corner is a true SF icon, may it last a hundred years.

jX52sZoojxyYV2viWNyO7A.review_text: We had a group of 20 and we were looking for a "family friendly" restaurant that served good, cheap food with appropriate portions.  Oh, and the place had to be tolerant of crying and moody kids, 7 of which we were bringing along...  Taking all those criteria into account, Capp's Corner fit the bill perfectly.   I had the Osso Bucco.   It was good, but it certainly wasn't amazing, and at $25 for the meal, it wasn't particularly cheap.  It's a pretty "funky" place in that it's old school, and I certainly enjoyed the meal well enough, but it still set us back about $110 tax and tip included (with a couple of beverages each) and I didn't really feel like it was worth the money.   I don't see myself coming back unless I had to.

wnjLfAVNDoUzlkm8SVptcw.review_text: Well, Sorry Greg. I didn't much like this place, and I'd like to think I'm *not* a pretentious asshole.     Went with family at the insistence of my brother in law, who described it as "old school" and "authentic Italian."  It may have been both of those things, but also wasn't terribly good.  All entrees were rather ho-hum -- sauce was not interesting, rich or flavored -- a tad watery.  Bread wasn't to my liking.  Salad was boring.  We had to ask for olive oil and butter and never got either (although she apologized many times once she realized).  What my B.I.L. ended up admitting, is that he'd gone here for years with his father when he was as teen growing up in San Francisco, so his recommendation was based on pure nostalgia, and had nothing whatever to do with the food.  We'd never return for the food -- there are simply better meals to be had elsewhere, at exactly the same *type* of place -- unpretentious.   One star for the funny waitress, however, who couldn't reach to the back to serve one of our diners. She said to my brother "Take this plate from me, honey ... my ass is too fat to get back there."  (My brother *actually* bent around and looked to see if she was right.  She was.)

DodFQgkojJ2hCXuI85RR3A.review_text: I went there over 4 months ago and had Veal Milanese Sautéed breaded veal with lemon butter caper sauce, a glass of their house wine.  We were seated right away since the place was not busy yet. The server and the host attended to us right away.  Bread came out shortly after.    The place reminded me of old-style San Francisco.  It had tons of photos of locals and nationally known stars.  It was very homey and had lots of large family-style tables.  It is clear that the place caters to families and lots of locals.  The place has a bar right in the middle of the dining area so it was kind of loud.  Especially when that lonely drunk was yelling across the bar at people he did not know and was getting into their conversations.  So, be forewarned that you might want to sit in the back away from the bar.  Back to the food.  I loved my food.  It was well cooked, seasoned, and I had plenty.  So if you are a light eater, this is not the place to go.    To early around 5:30-6:00, cause it gets busy right around 6:30 - 7ish. parking sucks, so allow 1/2 for parking in the hood.

80c1C8Wdj_gklIYOP_MV-A.review_text: I love "hole-in-the-wall" Italian restaurants, and Capp's definitely fits the bill.  The minestrone was excellent, the salad was good, bread was a bit of a disappointment (not sour dough), but the penne with Italian sausage, onion, and bell peppers was delicious.  The atmosphere is definitely "little Italy".  One deterrant only, can't mention here... but the food was great!

ziZds2vvl4g8bHciN8-6TA.review_text: This place is such a time warp for me.  I really love its old school no nonsense charm.  Rose is and was awesome.  We were here for a couple of drinks on New Years Eve with a few friends.  Loved it...

lCUazm0F3GhbVMM7J0wzuQ.review_text: Since we were in a rush and needed to have dinner, we ended up here since it was conveniently located right next to BBB. I had the spaghetti and meatballs and my bf had their lasagna. Each dish came with a minestrone soup and a salad. The soup was okay. The salad was nothing exciting. Just lettuces and a heaping of ranch dressing which I did not enjoy. Looking forward to my spaghetti...because how can spaghetti ever go wrong...i had one bite of the meatball and it was the worse I ever had. The meatball looked blacked and was extremely bland. Although their portions at this place is huge, what's the point if the quality and taste do not justify? And to top it all off, our 2 dishes came out to be around $40 with tax. For that kind of money, I would enjoy something else. Even McDonalds...

YdRlFZAkjUEhmO1KT7oKtg.review_text: yum, yum, yum....  it has great home-style italian food... you get minestrone and an incredible beet/garbanzo bean/iceberg lettuce creamy italian dressing salad with your entree.... its just fun! great for a crowd or a date night.  the bar is cool too but only if you're with a bunch of people

OniLiyqsK0qKv4kptqzipg.review_text: Time warped into historic San Francisco Little Italy.  The place is real humble - picnic colored table cloths, a well stocked bar, and real class act staff.  The host was take straight outta The Sopranos - loved the retro bowling shirt, the dew, and a real fun attitude.   A waitress dropped a bottle of wine that startled one of the guys.  He walked away clenching his heart mumbling something about an 'incident gone bad' back in the 60's.  It was hilarious!  All the items are family style.  Theres an $19 menu and a $22 menu, depending on the entree.  You get all you can eat minestrone soup and salad.  Both were average - standard but very hearty minestrone and a salad resembling House of Prime Rib (garbanzo beans, red beets, lettuce sloshed with thousand island dressing).  Was pretty full even before the entrees came out.  The entrees were delicious.  Had the Veal Tortellini with tomato cream sauce.  Wow this was really really good.  Perfectly cooked, creamy but not overly, and tasteful not heavy.  The Chicken Parmigiana was excellent.  Grilled with char but not fried.  Probably hammered down super thin and had great cheese and marinara on top.  Really good!  The veggies it came with were standard issue from the freezer boiled.    Overall the experience was nice.  Really feels Italian - a bit commercial but super casual.  Something perfect for a rainy and cold night like this in San Francisco.  Could use an upgrade on upholstery, but otherwise its a warm place.

FrEgyUjcmy9LOxfTdzQhFA.review_text: Topped off a perfect visit to SF from down peninsula fo three seniors.  Was great to see BBB, find easy access nearby parking at Vallejo Garage, and dine just steps from BBB at this couldn't-be-homier little spot.  We happened to arrive as a large busload of seniors from Grass Valley arrived - unbeknownst to waitstaff, who couldn't be more cordial and inviting.  I could definitely imagine stopping in frequently if I lived nearby.  At the invite of waitress and ok from bartender we started our meal at the bar instead of waiting.  Yes, the minestrone was lighter, less pasta-laden than I am used to but I found it a nice lead-in to the salad and entrée, rather than being too filling.  The salad was traditional, as expected.  We did love the luscious beets and remarked at the creamy dressing.  We were informed it was simply egg and olive oil! Whoa-tasted like creamy cesear or...  Each enjoyed our entrée and felt a 3 course dinner under $20 in 'the city' was great to come by.  Thanks to all for a lovely cold winters night out.  We've recommended already..

5rK8eYZHUvugbVoAjvUX0g.review_text: we felt 100% swindled when we left which of course ruined our enjoyment of the meal and i do not plan to return.   this place reminded me of the type of place my parents would take me.. kid friendly, cozy feel with the red and white checkered table cloth and family style pasta that we can all share and not worry about being to loud or spilling..so we thought.   the menu displays 3 options... family style for $18 with various pasta only options, family style $20 with various pasta and meat options, and an individual meal for $15. all 3 of these options come with soup, salad, and bread. the way it was read was that this would be the price for the family portion (at any other italian family restaurant i have been to this is enough pasta for 2-3 people). We ordered the family style chicken parm and our waitress told us for family style we get to choose 2 entrees which threw us off so we ordered the pork chop also to share. when we got the bill we were charged for 2 family style meals.. $50 with our drinks when we were under the impression our total price would be the $20 with drinks.   i asked the waitress to explain and she said that family style there only means we share the soup and salad and we each pay the $20 "family style" option. then she gave examples of families who come in and try to order family style for a table of 8.. obviously this means we were not the first to misunderstand their menu and she knew we didn't understand when she took our order and could have clarified then.   note to Capps: asking forgiveness rather then permission is not a good way to do business.. this may work for tourists but not return customers.   note to future customers: the food was very tasty and we enjoyed the environment casual dress laid back environment but for what you get $20 is to high.

wqUN9yXv_bJi4O7Z-bIHew.review_text: I am really surprised that Capp's has slide to an all time low.  The food was far from what it used to be.  The Sole was so rubbery that you had to saw it with a knife.  The fact that the staff was stoned out of their minds might have had something to do with it.  Several were taking terns going out front and getting stoned.  I do not care that they were high but the output of their efforts were not worth the money we spent.  As a past fan of this restaurant I am sorry to say that it comes off the list of places we eat in the City.

qh6Mkc7Xr-h0QdfY2atfoQ.review_text: Pros: 1) The busboy was the only person there that was friendly.  Cons: 1) Unfriendly servers 2) Impossible to get servers' attention 3) "Family Sized Portions" doesn't mean what it is supposed to mean. By Family sized portions, they mean the soup and salad, which doesn't make any sense at all. Everyone orders their own entrees, which defeats the purpose of "Family Sized Portions." 4) I got the Spaghetti and Meatballs, and I could have made it better at home. 5) The Clam Chowder was watery. 5) VERY pricey

AUF3-APCh1q_QD8AaMHRhw.review_text: I was having a little adventure with my friend and we decided to try somewhere new to eat. We found ourselves over by Capp's and decided to walk in.   It was around 3 when we walked in and we were the only ones there except for several people at the bar. We were brought the lunch menu and told the specials. I was debating on whether I should go with a classic Italian sausage sandwich or eggplant parmigiana. I decided to order the latter, a la carte.  We were given a basket of bread which seemed a little burnt but it was still good, especially with olive oil. It also went well with the eggplant parmigiana sauce. The EP was pretty good; there were three pieces of eggplant, a little side of penne, and a side of veggies. Overall, I really enjoyed what I ordered.

CnLNC8VMErPASEq_uimDaQ.review_text: Capp's has a special place in my heart.  I came to SF with my family a lot as a kid and we always liked to eat at Capp's.  Always eat the minestrone soup and the bread.  I get that people have gripes with Capp's because it has tacky, Bucca de Beppo style interior, but the food more than makes up for it.

p-rz5nElTuSyUV1Dzui6Yg.review_text:
Pretty darn authentic East Coast Italian. On some Thursdays they have an open blues jam. Sitting family style is always fun if the people you end up sitting with are fun, so it only improves the experience.
  Its a great place to eat if you are going to see Beach Blanket Babylon as its basically next door.

pq5zcn8SFFct5fUhDpe24A.review_text: This is the second time I ate at Capp's. Both times I had a great time - the atmosphere, the service are special and first rate.  Food is plenty (actually one could order one dinner and a second plate, and both parties would be satisfied).   The minestrone was fantastic and worth the admission alone, well almost. However the main dishes are average. Both times I was underwhelmed. I would've given it 2 stars, but the ambiance of the place and the minestrone are worth one additional star.

E60eQKsPuaFOiKi9vCTW7g.review_text: So my family took me here years ago and i was always thinking to myself where was that little cute italian restaurant that gives you SALAD, SOUP, and ENTREE!?! Sure enough we go there again and i lovve it!! FIrst of all the salad is pretty good! For everything your paying? And the soup, ohhh the soup, ive had minestrone soups everywhere, evvverywhere. The majority tastes like progresso soup company walked in there kitchen and poured all there can soups! This capp soup however is homemade and delicious!!! Perfect for those cold windy sf days right? The soup is one of my favorite parts about this place. The entree was pretty great as well! I had the mussels and clams linguini which was delicious. Go there for some yummy "home cooked" italian and bring your friends and family. If you want italian thats way over priced and pretty go somewhere else!

Bp-TQEtc6Vs6ldnLgjqglg.review_text: Let's not kid ourselves about the food. It's mediocre at best, but the size of the entrees and price doesn't hurt much at all.  This place is a North Beach neighborhood institution, with a cheerful Italian vibe and the one of the best host and bartender duos I've met.   It is a place where you roll up your sleeves and sit at the counter to talk with the locals or share a bottle of wine with your neighboring table(s).  Nothing beats the holidays without a visit to good ol' Capps for a drink and a hearty meal with good friends.

1Aiv-gmtJUVoId41CqpDEQ.review_text: You can't go back.  You know the saying.  Well, Capp's unfortunately fits this truism.  Years ago I went several times.  But somehow time has not been so kind to Capp's.  Let's focus on the strengths first.  Nice big bar.  Great place to get lit before waltzing over to Broadway and Columbus and getting thrown out of a strip joint for asking the wrong questions.  Very friendly people. Homey, cuddly, oh baby how's my snookums, here's a big plate of spaghetti, honey, love ya.  And that's where the problems start.  "Problems" is too strong a word.  Average sums it up.  There are a few high points.  The prices are lower for North Beath Italian, but there comes a point where even a Cheap Ass like me is not taken in by the price.  There are three prices on the menu and a selection of choices at each of the three price points.  Everything comes with soup, salad, side of spaghetti, dessert, and a plastic crab.  I'm kidding about the crab. But Capp's trys real hard to give you value.  I give them 4 stars for Value Effort.  The issue is nothing makes me want to rip my clothes off.  Or even unbutton my shirt and start singing, for Chrissakes.  The Osso Bucco was the best of the 5 entres that graced our table.  It was very homey, comfort food, brown sauce-y, reasonably good.  The soup was actually fine.  But other than that, I am afraid I would only come back for the bar.  Right before going to Broadway and Columbus to... oh, nevermind.

CiJat5Up2jAO3B0qTbiN5Q.review_text: This restaurant was a family favorite when I used to live in the neighborhood.  It's loud, packed, food is in huge portions... what more could you ask for?  Minestrone and salad are the classic starters.  And then just sit back and enjoy basically anything their menu has to offer.  I see promotions of this place for the Beach Blanket Babylon show, but to me it's an old neighborhood staple.

poKMUP5vdmsmIBRWgtnX5Q.review_text: Ambience and food sorely lacking.  Loud,cramped, and bland food. With so many fantastic restaurants in North Beach, one should go elsewhere.

IH1iOatR3UkGxuiZVD4Xqg.review_text: This is a very perfect place to celebrate a birthday or other occasion with a larger-than-normal group.  The food is good and classic and the atmosphere is fun.  The only drag is, of course, parking is near impossible. Try up the hill, if you have good shoes :-)

zM-wgtx033u-yHoxk_1GEQ.review_text: Great service! People are so friendly. They also gives lots of food. Bread, soup, salad, and then the main meal. We were satisfied even before the main meal! Great family restaurant.

4QgjwgYbvfRwbHEKuPaDug.review_text: Sunday night, 8pm, no wait, family seating.  Comparing the service here to Tadich Grilll.   Capp's wins hands down.  Great server, the place was packed yet they sat down us down quickly with a family from CO.    We ordered a bottle of wine and it was served promptly.  Soup and salad were delivered promptly, and we really enjoyed our entrees of pasta and chicken parm.  Have been here a few times before and the place does not disappoint.

UjAHXZHm9dJzbzK-h870Hg.review_text: This must be my lucky place due to the fact that I once won a raffle for dinner here and now this time, dinner was comp by the owners, The Ginella's.  This family style Italian restaurant has been here for eons.  Decor is cool with posters and celebrity photos abound.  A picture of Tom Ginella is post next to the two TV's facing the bar.  I can't help but notice baseball and football were on the two screens.  The meals here are simple, family style Italian and portions are huge.  Our dinner came with bread and butter, minestrone , beets and beans green salad, pasta, veggies, and Veal Milanese and leg of lamb polished off with spumoni ice cream.  I must have been very hungry as I can't believe I ate the whole meal.  Service here is great.  Seeing how busy it was on a Sunday night, the staff was attentive.  Parking can be difficult or park in the nearby lots.

_ijx1PqANQVFLGNWCibdig.review_text: Afterday a full day of well whatever we could crame into one day in the city my inlaws who live in SF were thinking of a place that would be good,comfortable and not have a long wait. They enjoy Capps and are regulars so off we went  to dinner at Capp's.  Capp's at dinner is not cheap - it's kinda like the Olive Garden in that your entree comes with soup, salad and bread but you have to pay extra while the entree prices are already high to begin with.  The soup was kinda bland but a sprinkle of salt was good enough. The Salad was kinda bland also so off I go to my friend the always there for you SALT. Bread was Bread what can I tell you..... Nothing in the menu really caught my eye so I got the Shrimp Scampi but with creamy sauce instead and on fettucini pasta (WTF - no Angel Hair pasta!!). The pasta looked good but once again the taste or should I say seasonings were lacking.....off to Mr. Salt again.... It was the same situation with my daughter's alfredo fettucini.... Even my inlaws who love this place were constantly sprinkleing salt on every dish- I do not enjoy going to places in which I am paying for tasty food but I'm left with the job of  flavoring it so that it is tasty. The food should come out yummy already.....AHHHH Anyhow, the ambiance was kick back, loud though and depending on where you sit cramped. But as compared to most places in this city I would consider it spacious. The owner was nice - he came over and chit chatted with us a little.... They do need to put some updated pics on their celebrity wall cause man I don't have any idea who those people are....funny thing was we were for sure that their was picture of Elizabeth Taylor,Ophra Whinfrey and young Michael Jackson but as confirmed by the waitress we were wrong so go figure..... Bascially I've had way better Italian food and for less money!!!

fj1Px899gEisDyZOanIcrg.review_text: SO disappointed by our experience here. After reading reviews on Yelp it seemed like a good place to bring family from out of town for a SF standard good for family style dining. I ended up embarassed to have brought them here. The waitstaff was awful and gave us complete attitude any time we asked a question and were generally unattentive. The restaurant was barely full, there were just a few other tables, so they weren't busy. The busboy was the only one on top of his game, and was very friendly. Not so for anyone else. The food was mediocre/average, and very expensive for what you got ($18 for a relatively small plate of fettucine). But I will have to say that the service ruined it for me. Won't go back...

EFyqM9FSEAAKsCIiY1bzxg.review_text: Another lunch at Capp's on December 19, 2013.  Excellent as usual.  The prices never change.  Where else can you get an excellent lunch for $14?

r6Uw1QCfYS1CKtVQrjupag.review_text: Lots and lots of regulars at this place! It seemed like most people in the place knew each other. A group of 4 of us just happened to be lucky enough to get a table without a reservation on a busy Saturday night. The entire staff was very friendly and the atmosphere reminded me of the TV show "Cheers".  Before your entrees are served, bread, soup and salad are brought to the table for everyone to share. The prices are decent and the food is good, we were all satisfied!  The only funny thing (not so much a complaint, just funny) was that I think our server was drunk! Actually, I know she was since I saw her taking shots behind the bar. That being said, she actually did a pretty good job! She was overly friendly (of course) and did forget to bring us our check after we asked, but other than that, she was fine. There's nothing wrong with having a little fun at work every once in a while! :)

Wdc_L1VlVDfqxtRArJHjfQ.review_text: Horrible service and bland food. I had to add seasoning to every single dish including the soup!

4khHC8aiQ-SyaNGdPGRmVQ.review_text: ALWAYS good!  Consistence is key here.  Old school Italian done simply well.

WRc1yA_1Lddz6YKC9VtPUQ.review_text: Found it. An Italian restaurant that serves food family style. As in big, filling Italian portions. Many Italian restaurants are seemingly not. More a new wave California restaurant with a pasta dish. Or a nicely decoarated Trattoria that charges an arm and a leg, has a good wine list and decent Carbonara.   Capp's is the place you go for some good food, hearty conversation, friendly atmosphere and the feeling of being ten pounds heavier. Walking in you are greeted by a version of your grandmother and seated promptly. If you have to wait. There is a full bar right in front of you.  Order the family style meal. It is moderately priced. And you get way to much food. Salad, soup, bread, pasta, and then comes your main entree. This is how you do it! Save the over priced thin crust pizza with mussels and California goat cheese for another time.  And the TRUE test of this place. Wine is served in glass cups, not wine glasses. Nonna would approve.

3xGTOnOzdqxdZjkaphk4qA.review_text: Went here for my Mother-in-law's birthday. All the food looked great, except for what I ordered. The veal I ordered was dried out, and hard as a rock. Maybe that is not there speciality. Don't live in the city, so I would probably go to Buca di Bepo instead.

8DKSh-Je6p11yEP7lNn_ng.review_text: Capp's has been a favorite restaurant in my family for three generations so far, and it's easy to see why. The food is yummy and the atmosphere is somehow reminiscent of older times.  The family style minestrone and salad is awesome. Capp's has the only minestrone I've ever liked. Boy is it good!  I love the veal parmigiana. It's cooked just right and has the perfect amount of cheese on top. Top notch. The pasta and steamed veggies are great with the entree, too. I had a glass of white zinfandel with my dinner and it really put the finishing touch on the meal. Wait.. I take it back.. the spumoni put the finishing touch on the meal. Big ol' serving and so good!

srj-v0WSYa-1gpmffbeypg.review_text: First and foremost, the food is cheap!  They're also just fine.  Had dinner here about 3 weeks ago.  Soup was not bad (unlike what another reviewer said, the ingredients in our soup was distinguishable, not mush), salad tasted fresh and my leg of lamb was quite tasty.  All for a little over $20.  What else can a girl who doesn't cook want?  The servers are a mixed bag though.   There  was one rather rude guy who sat us at our table and a waitress who, when she finally arrivved to work (several tables were waitiing to place their order.  But no one else would take them until she started her shift) was a very sweet one.  So, if you're on a budget and want plenty of decent food and not too fazed by a waiter who ignores you after bringing you to your table, this is the place to go.

JC99U5y-KAchZIjBhf_DiQ.review_text: I've only gone to Capp's for lunch, the menu is different at lunch, and there's no pesto pasta for dinner. It's a yummy place and prices are reasonable. Food is fresh and tasty. The only reason why it dropped a price was because some things have changed, portions are smaller than I remember. I've always liked the steamed clams and the shrimp and mussels spaghetti with pesto cream sauce. Those are the best.

1qgjpD9Iz4DtPklG0RgEOg.review_text: Perfect!! Service to food- awesome dinner after show up the street! Have many friends that drive 45 min into the city just for this place!

6gAcTsq6Eyur4yNFo-K_nw.review_text: After watching beach blanket babylon, these usually is the place to be.  With a homie atmosphere and a family style serving. Food here is really good.  If you like italian family style food i think Capp's can meet your expectations..:-)

btNAzOwxZR-mgQk-J7_BxQ.review_text: hello yelpers. Capp's is an interesting place to eat. If it wasn't for Beach Blanket Babylon next door, I'm not sure how long this place would survive. The food is ok. I've had better Italian food in Chinatown. What really pisses me off about this place is the disrespect that I received. When my gfriend and I arrived the hostess/waitress sat us in a corner table which is always nice and private. However, while we were sitting enjoying our "meal", she came back over to us with our check and secretly asked that we hurry up and finish because her boss/owner was pissed because we were sitting at this table they wanted to use for a larger crowd. Are you F'n kidding me! Is that my problem! We had just started with our entrees and you are pushing me out the door! Granted a table top of 8+ guests is more money for them, but WTF about the rest of us paying customers. I find it very rude to even ask a customer (in the middle of eating) to please hurry so they can sit others. The place had several other open tables they could have pushed together to accommodate the other party. Or they wait like every other normal restaurant does. I complained to the waitress and all we got were two weak-ass free drinks to enjoy at the bar. Plus they offered a free bottle of wine the next time we come in. Do they honestly think we are coming back? Go scratch yourself Capps!

yhvT5W0IDPx81zVE8_qwGQ.review_text: I have to give Capp's Corner five stars.    Service is excellent and will even accommodate large groups.  The food is outstanding and portions are large.  There is a full bar.  The tomato sauce used in the pastas is one of the best I have tasted, as the acidity of the tomatoes is tangy and perfect.  I wholeheartedly recommend the spaghetti and meatballs - I no longer THINK of ordering anything else because I find myself craving the meatballs and sauce.  The family-style soup and salads are also fantastic.  The minestrone is clearly homemade and has been simmering for some time.  (If you have ever made minestrone, you know that it thickens and gets better the longer it sits.)  I have also tried the sole (delish!), and the mussels, which come with a few large pieces of cheesy, garlic bread.  My boyfriend ordered the veal ravioli once and said the dish was pleasing.  This is a restaurant that my family adores.  We make plans to visit Capp's whenever we are in the city.  As mentioned in previous reviews, it is a San Francisco North Beach establishment with an old-time ambience.  I am hooked.

obG-AA8CvhYORG0GDyeixw.review_text: My friends and I were at the North Beach Festival this past weekend and the selection of food at the fair was so so. We scanned the nearby restaurants and they were packed. My friend suggested Capps after seeing it on Bay Area Back roads and trying it a few months ago. We walked the two blocks and walked in. It was defiantly that family owned been here since the gold rush vibe. Definite authentic feeling. Old head shots on the wall along with red and white checkered tables. The  bar was crowded with regulars and everybody obviously knew their name.   We were seated immediately. It took a minute for the server to come but when she finally did, she was very friendly. We placed our orders and waited for our drinks. First the bread came out. It was delicious!! I loved the artisan taste of it. Crusty on the outside and warm and soft on the inside. Every meal comes with minestrone soup and salad. The soup was good but the salad was amazing!! I love dressing and the garbanzo beans in the salad. Not something thats normally in a house salad but enjoyable. By this time I was already stuffed. I still had my lasagna to look forward to and was already leaning back in satisfaction. When our food came, I was surprised to see the large portions. We had already filled up on bread, salad, and soup, and I was not sure how we would finish our entrees. Even my friend who finished the pho challenge went home with leftovers.  I would defiantly go back to Capps in the future. I'm willing to overlook the parking situation in North Beach to fill up on the fantastic food at a fantastic price!! The bill for three of us including drinks was $81...I heard that its just as good for lunch for almost half the price.

Fepez6v1NidY-G8YDj_0kg.review_text: This is a family Italian restaurant that may not rival the food in Italy, but it will reel you in with the hospitality! Food was good with healthy servings. The staff and the welcome you receive upon entering and throughout your meal create the experience that is lacking in dining these days. You are a part of the family as soon as you enter and it feels like Sunday supper without the crazy in laws. Definitely a place we will return to.

6qEZ-1pK1pzaAgox8OXn9w.review_text: Great restaurant off of the beaten path. I had my birthday dinner here yesterday evening, really enjoyed the atmosphere and food. I had the LINGUINI WITH MUSSELS AND CLAMS, it was on point with the minestrone and salad before the entree.    Met a lovely lady who had lived in Telegraph Hill for 98 years, her entire life and started to talk about the changes she has witnessed in the city. Great wealth of knowledge topped off with a delicious dinner.   Will be back soon.

kCAcbbltX-M6GO6aQgYlbw.review_text: Excellent family-style, hearty,  Italian American fare. It was exactly what we needed on a cold, rainy night in SF. If you're looking for haute cuisine, you won't find it here, but you will get great food and service, and a lively, comfortable atmosphere.  What they did well: minestrone to die for and salad to savor. Yum! Pasta entrees, veal tortellini and meat ravioli had delicious sauces. The ravioli was cooked perfectly. Anyone who knows ravioli know what this means.  Could use some work: the bread was basic. Not bad, but nothing to write home about.  Overall, this was a great meal and we'll be back!

PKtB9kGhQvr3g22_3t5BXQ.review_text: Go here for the atmosphere, but not if you want good authentic Italian food. I was here with a group of 11 for lunch.   Service was pretty good though we had to keep asking for soda refills. Food came very quickly after we ordered & empty plates were quickly whisked away.   Started with salad with a creamy Italian dressing. Not bad, but nothing much to it - lettuce, canned beets, a few garbanzo beans. Lunch was the Cheese Ravioli Pomodoro. It came swimming in what looked like chicken broth (huh?) with anemic looking canned diced tomatoes. I was a bit scared to try it & never did figure out what the "broth" was, but the dish was okay.   Big thumbs down for the Parmesan cheese shakers. What real Italian restaurant uses the green-canned Kraft grated Parmesan cheese? This one does - for shame.   Didn't have dessert or alcoholic drinks, so can't comment on those. I'd come here again for the ambiance & a drink at the bar, but not for the food which is mediocre at best.

CtIcO-vIqRytQpXrN3lNIQ.review_text: The food was pretty meh. Meh bread, meh soup, meh salad. Entrees were fine but really nothing spectacular. Two stars for having bottles of wine for 20 dollars.   Service was horrible. HORRIBLE. Rude waiter.   I'll never come back.

i7OUiEm1HSvvXNb66Z7SUQ.review_text: Good for celebrations, my kids love it, cheap well drinks, solid and unpretentious atmosphere.  Food is good, certainly not out of this world good, but I keep coming back with groups and family cuz it's fun, one of a kind, an SF tradition and has flavor beyond the food.  Plus there's Courtney... I'm sure I prolly got caught by the missus with my eyes following her around the room, but that's OK, she's good at her job in addition to all that.  Not 5 stars for the gourmet experience, but the overall experience.

QfuxXxo3bKG0HiAiSoKO7w.review_text: This was great!  Professional, friendly service.  Wonderful food and drink.  Perfect location

II3SZQD1NE0zcN4fQqohug.review_text: My favorite resurant in SF.   Food is ok, but it is the atmosphere that makes this place special. The fact that Edie has been razzing customers since the 50's makes it that much better.   What other place can you get a turine of soup (the only minestrone I ever liked), a salad, an entree and a cup of spumoni for 20 bucks. Granted ten years ago it was only 13. But that is a deal!   Great wine selection too!

AGraTma9eEgsiJFDIy6tbg.review_text: 3.5 stars rounded up!    Before catching a show at Cobb's Comedy Club, we decided to stop by Capp's for a quick dinner.  I loved the yummy minestrone soup (great flavor, comforting, it hits the spot on a cold San Francisco night, brrr!) and the salad (nice tangy dressing and I love garbanzo beans) we shared.  I got the calamari steak (calamari cooked in egg, yummm, it was cooked just right and it was flavorful!).  The service was so nice & friendly and our food came out nicely timed and quickly (which was good because we were hungry!).  Grazie, Capp's - ciao 'til next time!

5CZDtRWuEw5-NQ5CN5Db-Q.review_text: How do you get just the right combination of family style Italian food, San Francisco attitude staff, and cheap, tasty grub? Hell if I know, but Capps Corner seems to have that recipe down to a science. One of the things I love about places like this in the city is the people are real. By that, I mean that they are not putting on some act, following several volumes of company rules and regulations. They are simply themselves, which is friggin awesome! No matter what meal you order, you receive a family style tourine of minestrone soup, and a family style bowl of salad. How can you go wrong??

yan0OV0G1jgv0TnQqj4TBA.review_text: Yeah...so the night started out like any other. Pondering where to go for italian food, me and two of my friends settled on Capp's, knowing little about it. We were delighted by the soup and salad course but the bowls that they were served in--ew! They were scratched up stainless steel mxing bowls. Anyway, so we ordered our entrees and then a forth friend was going to join us. When she did, we made the decision to share our three entrees with her, but they would not allow it. They wanted to charge her $12 for "soup and salad".  So we obliged and actually ordered another entree.  When the food came it was really nothing spectacular. I had the veal picatta and it was tough and the sauce had an off flavor. But, they hooked us up with dessert which scored them some points.  As we were enjoying dessert, I felt a small metal object in my mouth. Tainted food, you wonder? No actually my tongue ring had become undone. When I went to the bathroom to re-enstall it, it fell out of my mouth and into the drain. You should have seen the look on the bar tenders face when I asked him for a pipe wrench.
